column2: Managing a portfolio for retired people whose total income is directly tied to its success in the marketplace, is perhaps one of the most difficult of all investment challenges. But it is not a venture limited to the elderly; many younger people take on the task of managing their parents's money.

A radar technique that measures both the size and number of falling raindrops may give meteorologists more accurate estimates of the rainfall in storms, the National Science Foundation reports. Such accurate information on rainfall would be a significant aid in flood prediction among other things.

Speculators continued actively buying wheat futures yesterday after the Agriculture Department cut its assessment of the 1979 Soviet grain crop, and traders speculated that Russia could seek to buy as much as 10 million more metric tons from the United States in the marketing year beginning this fall than they are expected to buy this year.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)--Oil companies apparently helped create current gasoline shortages by stockpiling crude oil instead of refining it into gasoline, a top official of the Federal Trade Commission charged today.
SONOMA, Calif.--With all the fuss raised about wine in these parts, it comes as a surprise to most people to discover that what may be one of the country's best beers is made here, too.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 11 (AP)-- Dwight Evans's double and a throwing error by the Kansas City reliever, Al Hrabosky, opened the way for four Boston runs in the 10th inning tonight as the Red Sox recorded a 4-0 victory over the Royals.
MONTREAL, June 11--The Montreal Canadiens lost their successful coach today, and the Buffalo Sabres acquired a new general manager.
JERUSALEM, June 11--Prime Minister Menachem Begin today denounced domestic and foreign critics of his Government's, settlement policies and said "we shall pay no attention."
WASHINGTON, June 11--President Carter announced today that he would try again to increase the cutting of timber from the national forests in another attempt to check the rising costs of housing.
The price of gold continued scaling new heights in Europe and New York yesterday, while the dollar was mixed against the currencies of West Germany, Japan and Switzerland.

ALBANY, June 11--An agreement that would provide for state financing of the City University of New York appeared in jeopardy today because of Republican demands for additional state aid to private colleges.
PARIS, June 11--Nearly complete results from the European Community's first direct elections showed today a general move toward conservatism.

After telllng the National Security Council the other day that he would approve full-scale development of the MX mobile intercontinental ballistic missile, President Carter is reported to have said, "I feel confident with this decision."

MEN OF THE HOUSE Bloomingdale's is heralding Father's Day next Sunday with something different --the sound of music--each afternoon starting today in the ground-floor men's department of the store, at 59th Street between Lexington and Third Avenues.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)--The Carter Administration urged the United States Court of Appeals today to overturn a lower court ruling and restore the President's power to punish violators of his voluntary anti-inflation guidelines.

ROME, June 11 (UPI)--Italy's consumer prices at the end of May were up 14.5 percent from the year-earlier month, the Government statistics institute said today. The institute said May consumer prices were 1.3 percent above those in April but that the rise was lower than increases in January, February and April.

WASHINGTON, June 11--A White House task force on United States exports has drafted recommendations for President Carter that call for immediate weakening and eventual abandonment of key provisions in the law that prohibits payment of bribes overseas by American corporations.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The Supreme Court today unanimously overturned the conviction of a New York bookstore owner charged with violating that state's obscenity law. The Justices ruled that the procedure used by the police had deprived him of his constitutional right against unreasonable search and seizure.
Johan Neeskens, a top soccer player in Europe, signed a five-year contract with the Cosmos yesterday for a reported $1.6 million.

Construction has begun at 54 Pearl Street on a gallery for the Fraunces Tavern Museum. The Adeline Moses Loeb Gallery, next to the tavern where Washington bade farewell to his officers in 1783, is to be completed in October.

The delivery of 754 defective subway cars from the Pullman Standard Company has stirred division in the city government over how to deal with the safety hazards they present and how to settle a substantial claim against the manufacturer for late delivery of the equipment.
One old woman was antic and gray in her wheelchair, as if for her Eugene O'Neill's words were dancing separate little jigs: "And baby's cries can't waken her in the baggage coach ahead."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11-- Secretary General Kurt Waldheim recommended today a six-month extension of the mandate for the United Nations 5,800-member peace force in Lebanon. He criticized Israel for what he said was refusal to cooperate with the United Nations force.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11 (UPI)--Iraq's central bank today halted all financial dealings with Egyptian banks and companies, the official Iraqi news agency said.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 11 (Reuters) --Iran's banks opened today as new, Government-appointed managements were named. Bankers described business as normal, following last Friday's takeover announcement.

The American public, still not believing that there is an oil shortage, solidly prefers gasoline rationing to scrambling to find supplies or to paying still higher prices, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

Gerry Hart, a defenseman for the New York Islanders for all seven years of their existence in the National Hockey League, was not on the club's list of protected players for the expansion draft that will take place tomorrow in Montreal.

Gwendolyn Brooks, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1950 for her book of poems "Annie Allen," the first black woman to do so, will be the subject of a biography by George Kent, professor of English at the University of Chicago. Mr. Kent, who has had access to the writer's notebooks, found that she had...

Steel production in the United States fell to 2.8 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 2.7 percent from the previous week's 2.9 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

CONGRESS is considering giving first-time home buyers an individual tax credit as a substitute for the reduced-rate mortgages that some state and local governments have been providing through the sale of tax-exempt bonds.
TRENTON, June 11--A bill that would make abortions more difficult to obtain in New Jersey passed the State Assembly today, 51 to 17, and was sent to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that consumers who believe that antitrust violators are forcing them to pay higher prices can sue the violators for triple damages under the Clayton Antitrust Act.

WASHINGTON, June 11--President, Carter is expected to ask Congress tomorrow for an $18 billion national health insurance program that would pay an American family's hospital and medical costs above $2,500 a year, according to White House officials.
CLEVELAND, June 11 (AP)-- Three California players suffered shoulder injuries during the Angels' 9--4 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

AFTER the sound of footsteps and a slamming door, a man woke to find that the woman with whom he had been living had left him. And what did he do then? He started reminiscing. What else did he do? He danced.

INVESTING overseas is one of the hottest new strategies for Americans. Many American banks and money management companies are actively offering their new international expertise to corporations and pension funds, in competition with money managers from London, Zurich and other foreign financial centers.

MOSCOW, June 11 (UPI)--Trade between the Soviet Union and the United States in this year's first quarter fell 10 percent from the year-earlier level, but the balance of trade in favor of the United States grew almost 18 percent, the American Embassy reported today.
The white picture hook stands out against the dark wood paneling where the portraits of the Shah of Iran and his Empress used to hang in the New York agency of Bank Sanaye Iran.

CONCORD, Calif., June 11 (AP)--A mild earthquake shuddered through the Diablo Valley early today, the authorities said. The quake hit at 4:52 A.M. and registered 3.0 on the Richter scale, said James Stifler, a seismologist at the University of California Seismograph Station.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 11--A public investigation of the California Supreme Court--the first in its history--opened here today with the presentation of a written report on the preliminary findings. Next Monday it will resume with the court's seven Justices among the witnesses to be called.

A LINE BERNSTEIN was a leading New York scenic and costume designer whose work in the 1920's and 30's had a role in establishing design for the theater as a profession in itself. She helped found the Neighborhood Playhouse and went on after its demise in 1927 to work with the Theatre Guild, Eva Le Gallienne's...

MONTREAL, June 11--The New York Islanders, the top team in the National Hockey League during the regular season, and the Montreal Canadiens, the fourtime Stanley Cup champions, locked up the six positions on the league's All-Star first team announced today.
TOKYO, June 11 (UPI)--Japan's exports licensed in May were up 3.8 percent from the same month last year, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry reported today.
While the Yankees had a day off in Minneapolis yesterday, Reggie Jackson in New York had the splint removed from his left leg and replaced by an elastic bandage.
New Jersey lawmakers are moving fast toward recess, but before they leave Trenton they should take up at least four measures. Each will require the legislators to oppose some vested interest.
PARIS, June 11--Victor Pecci, the tall, looming figure with the rocketlike serve and diamond in his ear, is the only professional tennis player in his native country, Paraguay.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 11 (UPI) --Venezuela's production of crude oil through June 6 averaged 2,343,079 barrels a day, the Ministry of Energy and Mines reported today. The figure represented an increase of 335,698 barrels a day, or 16.72 percent, over the same period last year, the ministry said.

Super Valu Stores Inc., the nation's largest grocery wholesaler, said it had completed an agreement with the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company that will allow independent grocery retailers affiliated with Super Valu to sublet 73 supermarkets closed by A. P. earlier this year.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 11 (AP)-- Lisa and Elisa Hansen, separated Siamese twins, were upgraded to fair condition today, and for the first time doctors expressed some optimism about their future. The 20-month-old girls, joined at the tops of their heads at birth, were separated in a 16 -hour operation May 30. They were listed in critical but stable condition for a week after the separation, then in serious but stable condition.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)--The Justice Department today blocked a Houston annexation proposal that would have added 140,000 people to the city's population. The department said that the change would dilute the voting strength of blacks and Mexican-Americans.
Sequestered juries from State Supreme Court in Manhattan are sleeping as far away as Red Bank, N.J., and Riverhead, L.I., because of the shortage of hotel rooms in New York City.
To start the Metropolitan Transit Authority on its way back toward providing economical, reliable, safe transportation, drastic steps beyond the conventional are required.

MEXICO CITY, June 11--The Mexican Government said today that it hoped within 10 days to be able to cap an offshore oil well that has been pouring an estimated 1.2 million gallons of crude oil into the Gulf of Mexico each day.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Federal law does not require a college either to accept a student whose handicap prevents him from meeting the requirements of a particular program or to provide "extensive modifications"...

AN inflatable implant to treat male impotence that cannot be corrected without surgery has been used successfully in 234 carefully selected cases, according to a research team at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.
Albert E. Hitchcock, a prize-winning plant physiologist and pioneer in the development of herbicides, died last Friday at his home in Irvington, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON THE Skylab space station, a one-time symbol of man's ability to habitate space that now seems emblematic of man's inability to plan ahead, is slowly dropping back to earth, coming 100 yards closer to destruction with every revolution of the globe.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn.--Two years ago Laurel Vlock, a Connecticut television personality, attended the National Women's Conference in Houston and was "inspired by the impact of the women's movement." She was so inspired, in fact, that she came home and convinced 10 women to join her in applying for a local television license.

The cargo ship South African Constancia pulled into Brooklyn's Pier 6 at sunrise yesterday, her chief cook dead and a 19-year-old steward missing. The youth was presumed to have drowned in the shark-infested waters 150 miles north of Bermuda.
SANA, Yemen, June 6--Yemeni leaders are urging the United States to train and equip a special mobile force to defend their borders against incursions from neighboring Marxist Southern Yemen.

Two major producers of nickel, a metal used extensively in stainless steel and other alloys, announced price increases yesterday, bringing most of the nickel industry above $3 a pound for the first time.

It looks like a complicated surfboard. But it's really a chair-- well, not really a chair, but a perch, and it's for the beach. "It's for peekers," explained Mitchell Gold, the furniture buyer who first saw it at a furniture fair in Milan. "You stand against it, get the sun and can still take a look at who is passing by."

The Independent Truckers Association yesterday urged 100,000 owneroperators to park their rigs and join a nationwide work stoppage that already has led to sporadic violence and threatens to disrupt shipments of food to grocery stores.
Three foreign car manufacturers said yesterday that they were changing the prices on their cars sold in the United States, with one announcing price reductions and the other two price increases.

WASHINGTON, June 11--After 22 months in one of the Administration's toughest jobs as the first Energy Secretary, James R. Schlesinger has acquired an uncoveted reputation as the most criticized member of President Carter's Cabinet.

MOSCOW, June 11--Leonid I. Brezhnev today described his Vienna meeting later this week with President Carter as "an important stage of further development of Soviet-American relations" that would advance arms control and the prevention of nuclear war.

Harper Row Publishers reported yesterday that it had a net loss of $1.2 million for the fourth fiscal quarter ended April 30, in contrast to profit of $409,000, or 18 cents a share, in the 1978 quarter.

"I jog eight minutes a day," Mayor Koch said somewhat apologetically yesterday as he announced the 10th running of the New York City Marathon, to be held on Oct. 21. About 14,000 entrants from all over the world are expected to participate.
Eight works by the Asian American Dance Theater, including two new dances, will be presented June 21-24 at the American Theater Laboratory at 219 West 19th Street.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 11 (AP)-- Championship Auto Racing Teams, in what was called a "good-faith move" toward the United States Auto Club, said tonight it would not conduct a race at Trenton on June 24 and will present to USAC tomorrow a proposal to end the six-month feud between the rival racing factions.

GRANGEVILLE, Idaho, June 11 (UPI) --A DC-3 carrying 12 United States Forest Service employees on a half-hour flight dropped an engine today and plunged into a turbulent northern Idaho river. At least two persons survived, including one who walked 10 miles to a ranger station.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission suggested today that 200 pounds of highly enriched uranium might have been stolen from a Pennsylvania nuclear plant in the mid-1960's.

WASHINGTON, June 11--Both the State Department and former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger asked the Mexican authorities to let the deposed Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran enter Mexico from exile in the Bahamas, Administration officials said today.
WASHINGTON, June 11--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether New York State's most recent effort to provide state aid to parochial schools is constitutional:

Previews for "Got Tu Go Disco," a musical opening June 20 at the Minskoff, have been delayed until Sunday. The previews were supposed to have begun last Friday. According to a spokesman, the previews had to be delayed because "the sets were not ready." He added, "The June 20 premiere date will remain firm."
HOUSTON, June 11--Spring floods and heavy rains have sent a surge of water into the bays and shallow tidal zones of Texas and Louisiana, threatening to devastate this year's shrimp crop.

According to Government figures, a total of 187 United States airliners have been successfully hijacked since May 1, 1961, when Antulio Rameriez Ortiz, a 30year-old Puerto Rican became the first person to commandeer an American plane and force it to fly out of the country.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 11 (Reuters)--Turkey, bowing to Western pressure in return for promised massive aid, tonight announced a new "multiple-rate system" for its lira, amounting to a de facto devaluation of between 24 and 43 percent against Western currencies.
BONN, June 11--Otto von Hapsburg, the eldest son of the last Austro-Hungarian emperor, was elected today as one of West Germany's 81 representatives in the Common Market's European Parliament.

CRACOW, Poland, June 11--From his many sermons and speeches here, it is apparent that Pope John Paul II is calling for a partnership between Roman Catholics and non-Catholics for the betterment of human conditions and the enhance ment of human dignity.

HONOLULU, June 11 (UPI)--An Air New Zealand DC-8 carrying 134 passengers and 10 crew members bound for Aukland, N.Z., was forced to abort takeoff yesterday at Honolulu International Airport because of a tire blowout.

Federal law-enforcement officials said yesterday that they would join the city in investigating allegations that at least one Transit Authority official accepted bribes from Pullman Standard Company, the manufacturer of subway cars. The company's equipment has been found to be defective.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 11-- Thirty thousand Cambodian refugees have been forcibly returned to their homeland by Thai military authorities in the past four days, and 50,000 more will be sent back to Cambodia as soon as possible, according to Government and United Nations refugee sources in Thailand.
WASHINGTON, June 11--Amid a debate over the accuracy of its oil figures, the Energy Department is hiring an outside auditing firm.
Samuel L. Snyder, believed to be the oldest licensed plumber in New York State, died Sunday at his home in Yonkers. He was 97 years old.
Jesse Abramson, a sportswriter for 56 years who was noted for his coverage of track and boxing, died at the age of 75. An obituary appears on page D19.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, June 11 (UPI)--Pope John Paul II flew by helicopter today to the papal summer palace in the cool Alban Hills south of Rome for two days of rest from his historic trip to Poland.

WASHINGTON, June 11--Two officials of Prime Minister Abel T. Muzorewa's newly formed Government in Zimbabwe Rhodesia are planning to visit the United States later this week, presumably to press for a lifting of American sanctions, State Department officials said today.

HONG KONG, June 11--Vietnam appears determined to expel virtually all the members of its ethnic Chinese minority and is exacting hundreds of millions of dollars from them before their departure, much of it to repay Soviet aid and arms sales, according to refugees and intelligence sources here.
Winning battles but losing wars, the New York Mets defeated the Cincinnati Reds last night, 3-2, but returned Pat Zachry to the disabled list and received a negative medical report on Skip Lockwood.

Herbert S. Polesie, a producer and director in the early days of radio and television, most popularly known as a panelist on the radio and television show "20 Questions," died Friday at Mercy Hospital in Marina Del Rey, Calif. He was 79 years old and had lived in Marina Del Rey for the last year.

Sydney Maree, the world's leading distance runner at the moment, has found a way to continue competition despite an international ban on South Africans. As a result, he is expected to run the mile in the New Jersey Olympic Track Classic June 23 at Piscataway, N.J., and the Brooks Meet of Champions June 30 in Philadelphia.

A Delta Airlines wide-bodied jetliner carrying 207 passengers and crew members on a flight from New York to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was diverted to Cuba by a hijacker last night, the Federal Aviation Administration reported.

THE penal system, in its various guises, is suddenly public tele vision's most prominent subject. Sunday at 10 P.M., Channel 21 carried "Tattooed Tears," made at a Calilfornia center for young men-- it will be shown on Channel 13 next Sunday at 11 o'clock.

PAHUTE MESA, Nev., June 11 (UPI) --A nuclear weapon buried beneath the volcanic rock of Pahute Mesa was triggered today, sending out earth shock waves that were felt slightly in Las Vegas 110 miles away. The Department of Energy said that the underground nuclear test, code named Pepato, had a yield of 20 to 150 kilotons, or a maximum equivalent of 150,000 tons of TNT.

WASHINGTON, June 11--A Congressional panel leveled criticism today at Langhorne M. Bond, chief of the Federal Aviation Administration, charging that he had failed to delve into problems with the DC-10 engine mounts before the Chicago crash on May 25 in which 275 persons were killed.

The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported that it purchased $71.8 million of home mortgages yesterday at an average yield of 11.142 percent, the highest rate since the agency began operations in 1971. Last week, the rate was 11.042 percent.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation and its reinstated chairman, Felix Rohatyn, have made a forceful critique of New York City's new budget. What the budget has failed to do, they say, is reduce the city's force of 194,000 employees, about 8 percent of whom normally leave every year. Unless the city government disciplines itself and replaces no more than half of those who leave, it will need an incredible run of luck to...
WASHINGTON, June 11--The House of Representatives voted today to permit voluntary prayers in the public schools and to ban busing of students to achieve racial balance.
The advances of microsurgery that have made reattachment of severed parts possible means that witnesses can play crucial roles in aiding accident victims.

David Sucherman, controller and general manager of Fowler Rosenau, stock specialists and members of the New York Stock Exchange, died of a heart attack at the home of a friend Saturday night. He was 78 years old and lived in Far Rockaway, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The House Ways and Means Committee made two changes in President Carter's "windfall" profits bill today that would increase by more than $2.2 billion the taxes that the oil industry would pay on additional income realized from decontrol of domestic oil prices.

AMERICAN colleges and universities may face a far more serious enrollment crisis than has been predicted by analysts of higher education, according to the Census Bureau's latest enrollment statistics.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)--Retail sales across the nation declined for a second consecutive month in May, providing further evidence that an economic slowdown was in progress, according to a Government report released today.

TOWARDS the end of the collection of skits assembled under the title "Scrambled Feet," the four performers place a duck named Hermione on top of their piano. All interest centers on whether the duck will or will not fertilize the piano; meanwhile, Evalyn Baron, one of the performers, sings a song advising against sharing the stage with an animal.

One of the most persistent, annoying and misunderstood of all New York City's transit problems is the phenomenon of buses that arrive at their stops in packs of four or five, after long, busless intervals.

BASEL, Switzerland, June 11-- Major Western central banks opened a new drive today to control the explosive growth of international bank lending, which many of them believe is helping fuel another worldwide surge in inflation.

A 20-year-old Manhattan man who was sentenced last month to 15 years to life imprisonment for a burglary-murder in 1977 escaped yesterday from the Rikers Island Adolescent Reception and Detention Shelter.
WASHINGTON, June 11--The Carter Administration does not think registration for a military draft is necessary now, Defense Secretary Harold Brown said in a letter released today.

HOUSTON, June 11--Richard T. Lyons, retired president of the Union Texas National Gas Corporation and a pioneer in the use of scientific techniques in petroleum exploration, died here yesterday after a short illness. He was 83 years old.

The New York City Police Department ordered its field commanders yesterday to give special attention to preventing violence at gasoline-service stations in the city. There have been two recent homicides as a result of disputes among customers waiting on line to get to pumps.

TOKYO--The Japanese Government has before it a golden opportunity to change policies, and to begin, some 10 years late, to fill in the gaps in Japan's domestic economy and ease trade imbalances at the same time.

IN an intensive care unit at Bellevue Hospital, a doctor pressed firmly against the finger tips that Renee Katz had used to play the flute. The skin blanched, then quickly turned a healthy pink, bringing smiles to the faces of the doctors who had reattached her hand.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)--This year's winter wheat crop is estimated at 1.43 billion bushels, a 3 percent larger forecast than last month, the Agriculture Department said today.

Standing next to a cross, a prominent rabbi read from the Old Testament, while 50 Jews and Christians responded with "amens" last Wednesday in St. Peter's Lutheran Church on Lexington Avenue in Manhattan.
Gulf and Western Industries Inc. has reported earnings increases of 17 percent for the third fiscal quarter and 36 percent for the nine months ended April 30, setting profit records for the periods.

Saying that President Carter is "sorely lacking in the leadership that is so essential for the survival of our borough, our city, and, indeed, all of urban America," Stanley Simon, the Bronx Borough President, yesterday endorsed Senator Edward M. Kennedy for President in 1980.

Sidney O. Raphael, a lawyer and philanthropist, who served as chairman of the board of the Kingsbrook Medical Center in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 575 Park Avenue.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 12-- Refugees fleeing from nearby battle zones paused briefly today to contemplate the burned-out wreck of the opposition newspaper, La Prensa, which had been destroyed by the Nicaraguan National Guard a few hours earlier.

Top-grade state bonds were offered to investors yesterday at the lowest yields since last autumn as underwriters calculated that the rally in the credit markets would continue. Investors hung back and did not rush to buy.

RETAIL banking entails a specialized form of real estate that has been undergoing significant changes in recent years. As banks prospered, their branches become bastions of propriety with lavish building materials and vast space designed not only to accommodate the special security needs of banks but also to project an image of grandeur.

The Saturday cowboys who saunter through Bloomingdale's in hand-tooled boots and other Western trappings have something new to flip over: extraordinary silver buckles, some as large as saucers and set with a ruby or two.

JUBA, the Sudan, June 7--In luxury sedans and battered buses, by truck or canoe and on foot, tens of thousands of Ugandans, the privileged and poor alike, have fled to the sanctuary of southern Sudan.
Directors of the Traps World Corporation and Spartan Food Systems Inc. have approved a merger of Spartan into Traps World, the holding company that operates Trans World Airlines.

BERKELEY, CALIF. MENTION Berkeley to anyone over 20 and you conjure up images of golden youth in laid-back acade mia, of almost-forgotten 60's anguish, of hair long since shorn and of causes long since dropped.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)-- Business inventories climbed a steep 1.4 percent in April, the largest increase in a year, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 12--Some Congressional leaders reacted angrily today to reports that a White House task force favors taking steps to weaken the law prohibiting payment of bribes overseas by American corporations.

Victor Gotbaum, executive director of District Council 37, must remove eight of his aides from the staff of the affiliated union of municipal hospital workers because of objections by the local's president, a New York State judge has ruled.

LONDON CLUBS are out, restaurants are in. The slow demise of English country life is currently paralleled by a revival of cafe society with pretty and sometimes famous people competing fiercely for the best tables in trendy restaurants.
STRASBOURG, France, June 12 (AP) --The civil aviation authorities of 21 European countries today adopted a program aimed at putting European-owned DC-10 airliners back into service by next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON BLUE skies, flowering bushes, no reservations, no tipping, new entertainment daily, full meals from $3 down, minutes from the White House, the Capitol and major museums--few restaurants can match the appeal of a sun-blessed lunch in one of Washington's downtown parks.
WASHINGTON, June 12--President Carter has decided to phase out import quotas on specialty steel over the next eight months, the White House announced today.

TIME: the not-too-distant future. Place: a large Manhattan office building where, in accordance with Federal energy conservation regulations for summer, thermostats are set at 82 degrees and business is conducted in bathing suits. The boss wears custom-made swim trunks. The typing pool is awash in bikinis.

MILWAUKEE, June 12--A Federal district judge reserved decision here today on a motion by attorneys for The Progressive and its editors to revoke the preliminary injunction that has kept the magazine from publishing an article about the hydrogen bomb.

IN HER fine new collection of essays, "The White Album," Joan Didion speaks of "the freeway experience" as "the only secular communion Los Angeles has." She goes on: "Mere driving on the freeway is in no way the same as participating in it.

LONDON June 12 (AP)-A $250 million loan to help Venezuela increase its steelmaking capacity and reduce its imports was announced today by major British banking houses.
CAPE GRIS-NEZ, France, June 12--A flying machine pedaled by an American sitting on a bicycle seat flew over the English Channel today in the first crossing of the channel by a man-powered plane.
The stock market advanced along a broad front yesterday in the heaviest trading in more than seven months, with the blue chips and special-situation issues making the best gains.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, June 12 (AP)-- The predominately Democratic Western governors took aim at the White House again today, sniping at the Carter Administration's policies on wilderness, water and rangeland.

Ferenc Nagy, one of the first Prime Ministers of postwar Hungary and a leader of anti-Communist exiles fmm Eastern Europe, died yesterday in Washington. He was 75 years old and had lived in the United States since his ouster from the Budapest Government in 1947.
BOSTON, June 12 (AP)--A suspended jockey has admitted taking a bribe to hold back three horses in races at Pocono Downs race track in Pennsylvania.
TELEVISION may be awash in sit-coms and action escapism, but, not infrequently, there are moments of indisputable quality. The "elitist," too, must be served --at least occasionally.

HOUSTON, June 12--In a sharp move toward an extreme conservative position, the Southern Baptist Convention, the nation's largest Protestant denomination, today elected the Rev. Adrian P. Rogers president on the first ballot.

There is a yacht race in progress today somewhere between Newport, R.I., and Bermuda, one involving 34 participants and 34 yachts, one per person. It is a single-handed ocean race sponsored by the Society of Lone Offshore Sailors (SOLO).

The country fair will be coming to the city. At the first New York City Gardeners' Harvest Fair on Sept. 15 urban planters will have a chance to win a blue ribbon for their home-grown produce, and cooks may vie for prizes for their homemade breads, jellies, jams and pickles.

WASHINGTON, June 12--Describing the refugee problem in Southeast Asia as "a massive disaster," the United States condemned Vietnam today for virtually forcing all ethnic Chinese to leave the country. It also rebuked Thailand for forcibly returning thousands of Cambodian refugees to their country.

NEW DELHI--The summer monsoon should have broken over many parts of India and Bangladesh two weeks ago; so far there have only been a few desultory showers here and there. By mid-June it should be bursting in full fury along India's west coast and northeastern regions;

WHEN Emmett Dalton is imprisoned for second-degree murder, he writes to Eugenia Moore, a former school teacher who was his brother's mistress and a member of the Dalton gang as well. "Horse stealing," he writes, "was how we occupied ourselves in 1889 and 1890." She replies, "It seems rather headlong, doesn't it?"

WASHINGTON, June 12--Representative Morris K. Udall, who has been sympathetic to President Carter's bid for reelection without explicitly endorsing him, said today that "the peril point" for Mr. Carter's hopes for renomination would come if the President began running sharply behind potential Republican rivals in the opinion polls.
Alice Dalgliesh, one of the most revered figures in the world of children's books, died Monday at her home in Woodbury, Conn. She was 85 years old.

The union trustees of the New York City Police Pension Fund were ordered yesterday to end their three-month-old boycott of the fund's deliberations on accident-disability retirement cases. Justice Thomas J. Hughes of State Supreme Court in Manhattan issued the order in response to a petition filed by the city.

ALBANY, June 12--The Assembly tonight gave final passage to a $190 million reduction in the state's maximum income tax and also approved a $48 million salestax cut for manufacturers--a move that seemed unlikely only a few weeks ago.

Vinogradov, countered by complaining to the religious leader that the Soviet Union's image was being distorted in Iran.

CHICAGO, June 14--A strong new political force--forged from the proliferating local activist organizations formed to stabilize and renew neighborhoods-- has grown to maturity in America. ALBANY, June 17--The first phase of the 202d session of the New York State Legislature came to an end in the early hours of this morning as exhausted legislators straggled home for Father's Day. They departed after dumping a mountain of bills on Governor Carey's desk--but left enough business unfinished that they expected to return later this year.

A Manhattan man found a stick of dynamite in Riverside Park Sunday and brought it up to his West Side apartment before calling authorities who carted it away, the police said. They said that the unidentified man, who lives at 254 West 72d Street, apparently brought the dynamite to his home to keep it out of the hands of children.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)--Another rise in postal rates is likely in the spring of 1981, even though the Postal Service expects to have a surplus this year for the first time in three decades, Postmaster General William F. Bolger says.

She relaxes and moves slowly along the outer rail at Belmont Park, past the infield grave where Ruffian is buried.

LONDON, June 20 (AP)--Britain's output of passenger cars fell by 18.3 percent to an average weekly total of 24,231 units in April from 29,778 units in April 1978, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 20-- Energy Secretary James R. Schlesinger is expected to disclose tomorrow that most oil refiners have agreed to produce more gasoline during the coming weeks, Administration officials said today.

TURIN, Italy, June 20 (AP)-- Vladimir Tkacenko scored 29 points to lead the Soviet Union team to a 98-75 victory over Israel and the European basketball championship tonight, Yugoslavia, the defending champion, placed third and Czechoslovakia was fourth in the tournament.
WASHINGTON, June 20(AP)--The Carter Administration agreed today to review its plan to cut back on passenger trains and decided instead to preserve trains where ridership is increasing.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., June 20 (UPI)-- A low-yield weapons-related nuclear device was detonated today 1,100 feet beneath the Nevada Test Site. The test, code-named Chess, was not felt in Las Vegas 95 miles south of Yucca Flat and no radiation leaked into the atmosphere, a Department of Energy spokesman said. Chess had a yield of less than 20,000 kilotons.
Charlotte Seitlin, a former editor with Simon Schuster, died of a brain tumor yesterday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 72 years old and lived in New York City and Weston, Conn.

LOS ANGELES, June 20--Mattel Inc., the nation's largest toymaker, abandoned its popular slogan, "If it's Mattel, it's swell," sometime ago. The reason, according to one shareholder attending the company's annual meeting last week, was that, until last year, "things have been lousy at Mattel."
HARRISON, N.Y., June 20--In the quiet of the first green of the Westchester Country Club at 8:30 this morning, two robins were pecking away at the well-manicured grass.

Bill Stewart, a television correspondent for ABC-TV, and his Nicaraguan interpreter were shot to death today by a Nicaraguan soldier in Managua, the Nicaraguan capital.
TASHA THOMAS'S "Shoot Me (With Your Love)" was one of the grittiest and most rousing disco records of the last year and will probably become a classic of erotic dance music.

MELBOURNE, Fla., June 20 (AP)-- The Harris Corporation said today that it had reached a preliminary agreement to buy Consolidated Video Systems Inc. for $13 million in cash.

GENEVA, June 20--A police-court judge quashed 28 parking tickets today after ruling that two lawyers had the right to park in a space that seven state councillors had reserved for themselves. Judge Anne-Francoise Comte said parking space was too limited for it not to be open to all on a first-come, first-served basis.

HOUSTON, June 20--The Mets lost their third game in three days to the Houston Astros tonight, 5-4, as three members of the New York team were ejected in the ninth inning and as Joe Sambito recorded his second outstanding relief appearance of the series.

WASHINGTON, June 20--The Supreme Court, in a decision with potential implications for disputes over Indian land ownership throughout the country, today set aside a lower court ruling that had given the Omaha Indian Tribe title to 2,900 acres of bitterly contested land along the Missouri River.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 20-- Vietnam has agreed to a proposed international conference on Indochinese refugees, but only if it deals with humanitarian, not political, considerations.

LONDON, June 20--After deliberating for six hours in the murder conspiracy trial of Jeremy Thorpe, the jury retired to a hotel late this afternoon without having reached a verdict, and Mr. Thorpe, his bail canceled, was taken away to spend the night in jail.

The New York Stock Exchange, the nation's largest equities market, said yesterday that it had asked the Government's permission to offer trading in commodity futures through a new unit, the New York Futures Exchange.

ATLANTA, June 20--The bitter and violent truckers' strike appears certain to have a modest to sharp impact on supermarket prices as some crops in the critical Southeastern agricultural sector begin to dry out and rot, and there is the prospect of far more serious damage within a week if the strike does not break.

ALBANY, June 20--At the request of the State Energy Commissioner, the Department of Agriculture and Markets renewed its order late today allowing dealers to price gasoline by the halfgallon, effective at noon tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 20--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will try tomorrow to enlist members of the Organization of American States in a collective effort to halt the fighting in Nicaragua and to obtain agreement on a broadly based transitional government there.

The American Ballet Theater yesterday named Mikhail Baryshnikov, the former Soviet ballet star who is now with the New York City Ballet, as its next artistic director.

TOKYO, June 20 (Reuters)-- Japan's customs-cleared trade surplus narrowed to $33.2 million in the first 10 days of June from $988.6 million in the year-earlier period, the Finance Ministry said. The nation had a $495.6 million deficit in the similar period in May.

The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

Margaret Smith Court, Frank Sedgman and Jack Crawford of Australia, the late Rafael Osuna of Mexico, and two writers, Gladys Heldman of Houston and Al Laney of Spring Valley, N.Y., were elected to the International Tennis Hall of Fame yesterday.

PARIS, June 20--Guido Brunner, Energy Commissioner of the European Economic Community, discussed details today of the Common Market's proposal for a worldwide register of all petroleum transactions. An option to buy a four-block tract on the West Side of Manhattan owned by The New York Times Company has been granted to a partnership of two New York realtors considering large-scale development of the property.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan--Every month, 100,000 tons of crude oil arrive by tanker from Saudi Arabia at Port Sudan on the Red Sea to fuel the precarious Sudanese economy.

SUMMER is upon us, and therefore, so is a season of reruns. Efforts must be made to find the new and unusual. At least three choice specimens are available this weekend--two on television, the third on radio.

On the theory that a pound of meat in the freezer may soon be worth two on the hoof, shoppers have begun what is expected to be a prolonged home-freezer buying binge. The surge in sales has created some spot shortages and manufacturers' predictions of a boom year.

A blockade by truckers of a large food distribution center in Connecticut and apprehension about reduced shipments of perishable fruits and vegetables and meats marked the first day of the work stoppage by independent truckers in the metropolitan area yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 21-James R. Schlesinger, the Secretary of Energy, said today that he was "disappointed" because the nation's oll industry failed to increase its output of gasoline and heating oil last week, but added that oil executives had assured him that they would step up refinery runs in July.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Government officials said today that they had never been approached about acquiring Richard M. Nixon's estate at San Clemente, although last month a top Nixon aide said the estate, improved with more than $700,000 of public funds, had been sold to a private purchaser because "the Government has shown no interest in accepting the property."

The programming director of radio station WTTM in Trenton nailed himself into a transmitting booth yesterday and kept broadcasting a tune, "Cheapen the Crude or No More Food," that warns Middle East oil suppliers to lower their prices.

Completing its fifth sale of securities within four days, the Treasury yesterday sold $2.75 billion of four-year notes at an average yield of 8.89 percent, the lowest rate for such a maturity since last August but a rate slightly higher than expected.

A final settlement recently reached between the French Government and the heirs of Pablo Picasso will enable the Museum of Modern Art to mount the largest and most comprehensive Picasso show ever seen in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Following are excerpts from the text, released by the State Department, of a speech today by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance at an emergency meeting here of representatives of the Organization of American States:
Billy Martin returned to the dugout yesterday, but he clearly left his mark on the field as the Yankees struggled to another victory over the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-1.
TOKYO, June 21 (UPI)--Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira expressed confidence today that Japan would realize its 6.3 percent growth target for the 1979 fiscal year.

A month ago Godfrey Lukwongwa Binaisa's main occupational concerns centered on a mid-Manhattan trial lawyer's caseload of divorce actions, wills, negligence and criminal cases. Yesterday in Kampala, the capital of Uganda, he assumed the contested office of President of his homeland.
PEKING, June 21--China disclosed today a wide range of budget figures for 1978 and 1979, marking the first time since the 1950's that the nation has made public its overall budget data.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)--The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today tentatively approved the reopening of the Rancho Seco nuclear plant in California after the commission staff said that problems that forced the shutdown had been corrected.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Bucking tradition, the Carter Administration has been trying to get the Federal Bureau of Investigation to turn bank robbery investigations over to local law enforcement agencies whenever possible.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 21--After producing a very mixed first season and starting his second in lackluster fashion, Alvin Epstein, artistic director of the renowned Tyrone Guthrie Theater since 1976, has resigned. The Guthrie's board of directors announced the resignation this morning in Minneapolis.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 21 (AP)-- Illinois will soon become the first state to distribute Government-inspected marijuana for medicinal purposes, a state drug official said today.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI)--The Federal Election Commission today rejected a Republican plan to use the VISA credit card to collect political contributions and make some extra money on the side.

TACNA, Ariz., June 21 (AP)--Border Patrol agents who recovered the body of a Mexican alien and rescued 30 others from the Arizona desert this week fear that more may become stranded as temperatures soar above 100 degrees.

It has been found that, like a cosmic machine gun, the turbulent galaxy Messier 87 is emitting rapid-fire radio pulses less than a thousandth of a second long, each carrying the energy that 10 million suns would radiate.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance called today for the replacement of the Government of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle in Nicaragua and for urgent consideration of an inter-American peace force to restore order and democracy there.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 21--A Sandinist guerrilla aircraft tried to bomb the military headquarters of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle early today, but the bombs fell three miles away in a residential district.
Walt Whitman liked summer evenings. For him, last night would have been the first "mad naked summer night" of 1979.

WASHINGTON, June 21--The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, citing the growing refugee crisis in Southeast Asia, has asked the United States and other key nations to double the number of Indochinese given haven.
BAR HARBOR, Me., June 21 (AP)--A fire today destroyed the Jordan Pond House, a fashionable 19th-century meeting place donated to Acadia National Park 39 years ago by John D. Rockefeller Jr.

WNYC-TV, the municipally owned nonprofit station on Channel 31, has begun to explore the possibilities of raising money for its support through the leasing of air time for educational and public-service purposes.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)--Vice President Mondale will make an official visit to China in late August as President Carter's personal representative, the White House announced today.

HARTFORD, June 21--Connecticut's civil preparedness center, a collection of nondescript offices and desks in the back of the State Armory here, is normally manned during snowstorms, so it might not have been that odd when a man called in asking how he could get gas for his snowmobile.

Tugboat owners and striking crewmen reached a tentative agreement yesterday that is expected to end an 82-day walkout that has resulted in the diversion of $1.7 billion in cargo from New York Harbor to other ports.
RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, June 21-- Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia has urged the United States to start an immediate "dialogue" with the Palestine Liberation Organization.
EAST NORTHPORT, L.I., June 21--For women in the suburbs, two things have long been their bane: waiting in lines--at supermarkets, at banks--and acting as chauffeur for the family.
Salomon Brothers is applying for membership on the nation's two largest commodities exchanges following a similar entry into commodities by Goldman, Sachs Company earlier this year.

ROCK music is full of "hidden geniuses"--musicians who haven't ever attained mythic stature, but who still com mand a cult of fans who regard them as hipper and more talented than almost anybody else. An example of that phenomenon is Lowell George, who will be appearing at the Bottom Line tomorrow and Sunday nights.

When the drummer Max Roach takes one of his melodic solos, his precisely tuned drum kit fairly sings. And for some years now, Mr. Roach has been a leading innovator in the integration of voices into jazz. "It's because of the possibilities the voice offers," he said the other day. "Voices can growl, they can groan."
Mayor Koch went to the City Hall parking lot yesterday to demonstrate a new antiscofflaw device called a French boot and was summarily presented with a car to give the boot to.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 21--South Korean dissidents are charging that President Carter's visit next week has touched off a wave of repression, including house arrests, kidnappings and beatings by government agents at a time when both South Korean and United States officials are reporting improvements in human rights policies.

WASHINGTON, June 21--A trucking industry organization said today that more than 40 percent of the major carriers' overall hauling capability had been shut down in the first day of a threatened broad work stoppage by independent truckers protesting the rising price and scarcity of diesel fuel.

WASHINGTON, June 21--At their Vienna meeting cast weekend, President Carter raised with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, Washington's desire to fly U-2 aircraft over Turkey to monitor Moscow's compliance with the new strategic-arms agreement, but the issue has not yet been resolved, Administration sources disclosed today.

The coaches and players of the Cosmos agreed yesterday that Wednesday night's 3-2 loss to the Minnesota Kicks was a result of poor goalkeeping by Jack Brand and the inadequacy of two of the three midfielders.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)-- Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal told Congress today, that President Carter's plan to raise interest rates for smaller savers was a potent anti-inflation weapon that could prevent a recession.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Federal health officials have concluded that paraquat, the herbicide used to kill marijuana plants, may seriously harm the lungs of smokers and have suggested that spraying of Mexican fields be stopped.

Consulting the diaries of that tireless New Yorker, John Singleton Strong, for insights into the first day of summer, which was yesterday, we read from his entry of June 21, 1837: "Saw an extract from some foreign periodical ascribing this queerest, dampest, cloudiest of all springs and summers, to the influence of Halley's comet. It seemed as if some extraordinary agent must be at work."

Thousands of independent truckers have begun what their organizers call an "extended vacation," forcing a halt to much transport by a combination of violence and fuel-pump blockade. They vow to obstruct the nation's hauling until the Government meets their demands for higher shipping rates, more diesel fuel and relief from limitations on the weights they may carry and the speeds at which they may drive.

A 37-year-old Whitestone, Queens, man who lived with his parents apparently went berserk during a family argument last night and stabbed his father and mother with a kitchen knife, according to the police.

John G. deRoos, the $60,000-a-year, full-time senior executive officer of the New York City Transit Authority, performed outside legal work for pay "on several occasions" for the private law firm of Harold L. Fisher, according to accounts by the two officials and others. During that time Mr. Fisher was a member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board and later was chairman.

WASHINGTON, June 21--United States and Yugoslav officials describe Serbian and Croatian emigres engaged in terrorism in this country as tiny bands of desperadoes driven mainly by frustration over improving relations between Belgrade and Washington.

IT takes a little getting used to, but a half-hour or so in the company of the Royal Danish Ballet soloists now at the City Center-55th Street Theater is enough to acclimate even the ardent devotee of Russianstyle pyrotechnics to the gentler art of August Bournonville, the 19th-century Danish choreographer.
WASHINGTON, June 21--Americans for Democratic Action, a bastion of organized liberalism, will lead a fight to dump President Carter from the 1980 Democratic ticket, the group's leaders said today.

A 46-year-old drifter from Georgia who spent almost six months in jail--part of the time on a murder charge of which he was innocent--was freed yesterday alter the city's Commissioner of Social Services intervened. The prisoner, Charles Brooks, had been held since April 3, when the murder charge was dropped, because he could not raise $150 bail on an auto-theft charge.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 21--Last week Assadollah Mobasheri, the Minister of Justice in the revolutionary Government, issued a rather long appeal to Iranian entrepreneurs who fled abroad as the Shah fell from his throne.
AREA A--The Avalon Shoals area off Margate has come alive with bluefish and weakfish in large numbers. Fishermen have made catches of up to 50 fish, each running between a pound and two pounds.

EASTBOURNE, England, June 21-- The four top-seeded players advanced in predictable fashion to the semifinals of the $100,000 Eastbourne grass tennis tournament today, all winning their matches in straight sets.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 21-- Hundreds of hymn-singing, Bible-carrying supporters of Brother Lester Roloff, responding to his call for "another Alamo," have fought the State of Texas to a standoff.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)--President Carter, in a Fourth of July statement, said today that freedom and justice were not permanent and "must be constantly re-won in a thousand daily battles." He said the heritage received from our forefathers "was not a perfected nation, but the dream of a nation dedicated to the fulfillment of the highest human ideals and aspirations."

SYDNEY, Australia, June 21-- The Soviet Union has increased its purchases of Australian wheat, ordering more than 40 million bushels in the last month, an action that Government agricultural officials here see as confirming predictions of a poor harvest in Russia this year.

OKLAHOMA CITY, June 21 (AP)-- Federal District Judge Frank Theis formally accepted the jury's $10.5 million verdict in the Karen Silkwood damages suit today, and refused a request by the Kerr-McGee Corporation to interview the jurors.
Free outdoor workshops in music, drama and art will be featured tomorrow from noon to 4 P.M. at Wave Hill, Independence Avenue and West 249th Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.
Lawrence Stanley Lesser, a former New York and Washington lawyer, died Wednesday in Good Samaritan Hospital in Baltimore after a brief illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Washington.
Examining the entries at Belmont race track on a recent Friday, I was astonished to note that among them was a filly bearing the odd name of Euphrosyne.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)--An additional 730,000 metric tons of United States grain, equivalent to 26.8 million bushels, has been sold to the Soviet Union, the second big sale reported this week, the Agriculture Department said today. Sales of 700,000 tons of corn to the Soviet Union were announced on Wednesday.

HARTFORD, June 21--Governor Ella T. Grasso this morning signed into law a bill banning smoking in retail food stores, in parts of health-care facilities and in restaurants seating more than 75 people, unless they have special no-smoking areas.

Nathan Maidenbaum of Lawrence, L.I., the president of Associated Food Stores and a Jewish community leader long connected with Yeshiva University, died Tuesday of a heart attack at the age of 65. He was stricken as he was reading an original poem at the installation of his son-in-law, Rabbi David Schreiber, as president of the Hebrew Academy of Long Beach, L.I.

If you can't get enough of country music, the Princeton Country Music Festival in New Jersey tomorrow may be just the thing for you. Billed as the largest outdoor country music festival in the Northeast this year, the event, at Palmer Stadium, will last nine hours-- from 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.--and feature 10 popular country music acts, including Roy Clark, the Oak Ridge Boys, Larry Gatlin and the Earl Scruggs Revue.

One of the most fearsome words for Russian farmers is sukhovey, their term for the hot, dry winds that wither crops and turn the earth to dust. A sukhovey has been sweeping the Soviet Union's grain belt in recent weeks, and it is expected to force that country into making major grain purchases that could drive up the price of food around the globe.

A LOT of people love prints, and why not? Prints are fun to look for, fun to find, fun to take home and fun to hang on the wall. By "prints" I do not mean reproductions, facsimiles or any other form of counterfeit.

News of a first-quarter United States trade surplus failed to buoy the slumping dollar on the world's foreign-exchange markets yesterday. The price of gold was higher as the dollar fell to its lowest point against the Swiss franc since Feb. 7.

The City Investing Company, which owns 5.1 percent of Stokely-Van Camp Inc., the Indianapolis-based food company, was ordered yesterday to cease and desist in any further purchases of Stokely stock until it complied with Indiana's newly passed state takeover law.

A 45-year-old Serbian nationalist who hijacked an American Airlines jetliner on a flight from New York to Chicago Wednesday afternoon surrendered to authorities in Ireland yesterday, minutes after he landed at Shannon Airport in a second commandeered plane.

COPENHAGEN, June 21 (Reuters)--Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said today that his country wanted the chaotic pricing system of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries replaced by unified prices, but he added that Saudi Arabia would never allow the group's prices to rise to $20 a barrel.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 21 (UPI)--New Zealand devalued its dollar by 5 percent today to a near parity with the United States dollar. Before the devaluation, the New Zealand dollar was worth $1.0551 in United States currency. The devaulation made the New Zealand dollar worth $1.0023, a spokesman for the nation's reserve bank said.

District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx said last night that his office was investigating reports that a beating administered by policemen contributed to the death of a Harlem man. The death of the man was reported as resulting from injuries suffered in a car crash.

New tracking data indicate that Skylab may fall to earth four days earlier than previously predicted, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday. July 12 is now the most likely re-entry date.

The basic measure of the money supply declined by $2.6 billion in the week ended June 13, partially offsetting the record $6.9 billion increase of the previous week, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Yesterday morning, with evennumbered plates on an odd-numbered day, he went looking for gas.

CHICAGO, June 21 (UPI)--Consumers are more concerned with the availability of gasoline than its price, a top recreation industry executive said today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP)--The House Agriculture Committee voted to day to restore a provision that for nine years allowed poor people to deduct medical and dental bills from their gross income when applying for food stamps.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 21--Two men claimed Uganda's highest office today as thousands of citizens poured into the streets of Kampala to protest yesterday's dismissal of Yusufu K. Lule after only 68 days as President. Two persons were reported killed and 50 people injured in a series of demonstrations that began after midnight last night.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (Reuters)-- The new world trade agreements could save Americans as much as 2.2 percent on Japanese television sets and stereos and permit the United States computer industry to cut prices by up to 1.9 percent on equipment sold in Europe, according to an analysis released by the Government today.

Preceded by rites melding centuries of ecclesiastical tradition to the needs of the present, work resumed yesterday on the completion of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Morningside Heights, the world's largest Gothic structure.

The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 8 million shares in the month ended June 15, the largest increase for one month on record, to 47.6 million shares, also a record.
WASHINGTON, June 21--The Carter Administration scored a narrow but important victory today as the House of Representatives approved legislation to carry out the Panama Canal treaties.

EL PASO, June 21--Construction has begun on a controversial United States Immigration and Naturalization Service fence that will replace the dilapidated barrier separating this city from Juarez, Mexico.
Who Is Affected: Drivers of all registered motor vehicles, including motorcycles. Aircraft are not affected.

American banks lent $500 million more to their foreign branches than they borrowed from them in the week ended June 13, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. It was the first such net outflow since the week of May 9.

ONE of the most startling moments in all of ballet occurs at the close of George Balan chine's "La Sonnambula." A woman in a white nightgown, the sleepwalker of the title, picks up the limp body of a man and carries him off, cradled in her arms.

WASHINGTON, June 21--For the first time in more than two years, the United States has shown a quarterly surplus in international business transactions, in trade and services, Government figures showed today.

OCEAN GROVE, N.J., June 21-- Ocean Grove, a seaside sanctuary for Methodists where strict religious tenets have, for over a century, prohibited a wide variety of activities on Sundays, including swimming, was today declared an unconstitutional creation of the state.

STRASBOURG, France, June 21-- Margaret Thatcher, Britain's new Conservative Prime Minister, said today that she would make available $4 billion from her country's gold and dollar reserves to buttress Western Europe's new monetary system, of which Britain is not a member.

Otto W. Ergenzinger, retired vice president of Sterling Drug Inc. of New York, died yesterday at his home in Manhasset, L.I. He was 88 years old.

Citicorp, which earlier this month was ordered by the Supreme Court to divest itselt of its ownership of the Advance Mortgage Corporation, is planning to retain most of the mortgage company's business, according to a source within Citicorp.

JUNEAU, Alaska, June 21 (UPI)-- The Coast Guard cutter Munro today seized the Korean fishing vessel Dong Won No. 31 for violating the 200-mile fishing zone of the United States, a Coast Guard spokesman reported. The boarding party also discovered that the amount of fish in the hold of the vessel exceeded the amount recorded in the ship's log.

TEL AVIV, June 21 (Reuters)--Three Arab youths were killed today by an explosion in a house near Jenin, on the occupied West Bank, Security sources said they were apparently building a bomb.

Hilton International will manage a 550-room luxury casino-hotel planned for Atlantic City by the Cavanagh Communities Corporation of Miami, it was announced today. The two companies said they had reached an agreement on managing the Vista Royale Hotel, part of an $80 million hotel casino complex scheduled to open in 1981.
Lee McPhail, president of the American League, said yesterday that Bob Lemon would manage the league's team in the AllStar Game against the National League at Seattle July 17.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 17--The entrance hall of San Andres University, Bolivia's center of higher studies, is filled each evening with thousands of students talking excitedly over the din of competing loudspeakers proclaiming political statements.

WASHINGTON, June 22--The Chrysler Corporation received assurances today from senior Administration officials that they would consider steps to help the financially ailing auto manufacturer.
WASHINGTON, June 22--Carter Administration officials said today that Cuba was heavily engaged in supplying arms and training instructors to guerrilla forces in the civil war in Nicaragua.

Patricia Clare Kerman, director of the speech pathology and audiology service at Goldwater Memorial Hospital-New York University Medical Center, was married in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday to Sylvain S. Lerner, vice president of the Controlled Acoustics Corporation in Hartsdale, N.Y., specialists in noise control. Rabbi Jack Stern performed the ceremony in his study at the Westchester Reform Temple.
Chrysler common stock jumped nearly 32 percent yesterday following a rumored takeover offer by Volkswagen.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22--It started last year as a routine matter when the San Francisco Recreation and Park Commission raised by 5 cents the price of hot dogs and beer at Candlestick Park, home of the Giants baseball team and the football 49ers.

A new-two-hour production of William Gibson's "The Miracle Worker," starring Melissa Gilbert and Patty Duke Astin, will be one of three plays presented under the rubric of "NBC Theater" next season, the network announced yesterday.

The New York Court of Appeals has sent a disappointing but truthful message to parents who want to sue society for failing to educate their children. Charges of educational malpractice have been filed in courts across the country by the dismayed parents of illiterate and unemployable young people, seeking payment for damages and other relief.
BONN, June 22--Volkswagenwerk A.G. forcefully denied today that it was planning to begin a takeover offer for the Chrysler Corporation, the thirdlargest American automobile company.

The Federal Environmental Protection Agency is threatening the New York metropolitan area with the loss of millions of dollars because the state has no program for yearly emission inspections of the region's 3.5 million cars.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP)--Gerry Cheevers, the Boston Bruins' No. 1 goaltender, had torn cartilage removed from his left knee through an arthroscope today. He was expected to have some use of the knee within a week. He is the only goalie virtually certain to be back with the team next season. Gilles Gilbert and Jim Pettie are free agents.

WASHINGTON, June 22--A United States Court of Appeals overturned today a decision by a lower court and ruled that President Carter had the authority to use the Government's purchasing power to enforce wage and price guidelines.

New York City investigators are looking into charges of mismanagement and misappropriation of Federal and city funds at 10 South Bronx poverty programs that receive a total of more than $13 million a year in government funds.

WASHINGTON--Nearly three years ago, Congress passed legislation that was supposed to enable the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate chemicals regarded as hazardous to humans and the environment.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 22--The Syrian Government said today that religious zealots of the Moslem Brotherhood movement raided a millitary academy at Aleppo last Saturday, killing 32 cadets and wounding 54. The Government vowed to "liquidate" the movement, which it had tolerated.
MOSCOW, June 22--Andrei Voznesensky, the Soviet poet, has quietly withdrawn support from a group of writers who challenged the censorship system last winter.

WQXR-AM and FM will be playing rarely heard performances of the New York Philharmonic during the "Playback Festival," begining July 8 and continuing to the end of September, on Sundays from 3 to 5 P.M.

Because of trash-removal problems during the tugboat strike, alternateside parking regulations will be in effect today in Manhattan and the Bronx only. On Monday, they will be in effect in Manhattan and Queens only.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)--The Social Security system is at a critical juncture and must win public confidence anew by tackling such problems as discrimination against women, Commissioner Stanford G. Ross said today.

Richard I.N. Weingart, a New York businessman for many years, died Wednesday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., following a brief illness. He was 82 years old and had lived in West Palm Beach for the last two and a half years.

After a seven-year absence, the Netherlands Dance Theater will return to New York for a two-week season at the City Center 55th Street Theater, 131 West 55th Street, starting July 9.

Troy Archer, a 24-year-old defensive lineman for the New York Giants, was killed last night in an accident in North Bergen, N.J., involving a pickup truck and a telephone pole, according to the police. Few details of the accident were available.

CLEVELAND, June 22--Ten years ago residents of this industrial city gathered along the banks of the Cuyahoga River after a fire spread along its surface, which was covered with oil and debris. Two bridges were damaged, and the river was turned into a national symbol of environmental degradation.

TOKYO, June 22 (AP)--Deng Xiaoping, senior Deputy Prime Minister, told a high Japanese official that China was prepared to allow 100 percent foreign-owned businesses to operate in China, Japan's Kyodo news service said today.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP)-- The flow of funds into mutual funds last month totaled $2.7 billion, a record monthly gain, the Investment Company Institute reported today.
LONDON, June 22--At the end of a long and dramatic trial, Jeremy Thorpe was found not guilty today of having conspired to murder a man who claims to have been his lover.

Ray Whittaker, a retired theatrical manager for Shubert enterprises, died Thursday at his retirement home in Ormond Beach, Fla. He was 79 years old.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27-- Bjorn Borg and John McEnroe, seeded as the best two players in the men's singles field at Wimbledon, came close to being eliminated in the second round today, but in the style befitting the 102year-old tournament they fought their way back out of trouble.

WASHINGTON--In an important sense, the case for substantial progress by blacks in recent years is a creation of neo-conservative intellectuals who, radicalized to the right by the 1960's, learned to make their new principles pay.
WASHINGTON, June 27--The Carter Administration called on striking independent truckers today to go back to work and offered a plan to protect drivers who chose to defy pickets and return to the road.

SAPPORO, Japan, June 27 (UPI)-- Von Hayes of St. Mary's University smashed a homer in the bottom of the 11th inning to give the American college all-stars a 5-4 victory over Japan in the fourth game of the annual United States-Japan college baseball series today. It was the Americans' first victory in the four-of-seven-game series.
STOCKHOLM, June 27 (UPI)-- Unless the Swedish Government comes up with $1.6 million, a large part of the nation's cultural heritage will literally just fade away.

MEMPHIS, June 27 (AP)--Alan Fortas, nephew of the former Justice Abe Fortas of the United States Supreme Court, has been charged with attempting to bribe a penal farm officer to place his brother on a work-release program.

The credit market advance that began late Monday morning continued early yesterday and then bond prices fell back, depressed largely by a disappointingly large trade deficit for May. At the end of the day, fixedincome security prices were close to their Tuesday levels.

WASHINGTON, June 27--The Supreme Court ruled today that private employers can legally give special preferences to black workers to eliminate "manifest facial imbalance" in traditionally white-only jobs.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 27 (AP) --The evangelist Lester Roloff has agreed to remove the last five girls from one of his homes for wayward youths, temporarily ending his six-year battle with the state over his unlicensed facilities, state officials said.

KUWAIT--This oil-producing, taxfree welfare state appears to have absorbed the shock of the revolution in neighboring Iran, but it is keeping a wary eye on the shaky Persian Gulf region and the constant impact on its own politics of the Arab-Israeli confrontation.

CHICAGO, June 27--Both United Airlines and American Airlines increased their passenger loads with a three-week coupon promotion that ended June 17, according to preliminary reports from both carriers. But they say that accurate counts are still pending and that they still do not know how much their success cost them.

Directors of the Lincoln National Corporation, an insurance holding company based in New York City, and of the Security-Connecticut Life Insurance Company, Avon, Conn., agreed yesterday to merge Security into Lincoln. The terms provide for Security stockholders to receive $42 in cash for each share, making the total transaction worth $122 million.
Msgr. Francis J. McKeon, pastor emeritus of St. Ursula's Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y., died Sunday in Asbury Park, N.J. He was 76 years old.

Striking tugboat crewmen overwhelmingly ratified a new contract yesterday and began returning to their jobs. Their return to work assured a quick resumption of normal operations after an 88-day strike that disrupted port operations and garbage collection in New York City.
The 30th annual Pennsylvania Dutch folk festival opens Saturday for one week and will feature traditional Amish food, art and crafts.

New supplies of gasoline trickled into the metropolitan area yesterday and more were promised as New York state and city officials stepped up their enforcement drive against price gouging at pumps.

Sporadic violence, demonstrations and scattered layoffs persisted in some areas of the country yesterday as the nationwide work stoppage by independent truckers entered its third week. However, in other regions the strike showed signs of abating.

In a move that took the staff by surprise, Edward Kosner was replaced as editor of Newsweek yesterday by Lester Bernstein, a former managing editor of the magazine. Mr. Bernstein left Newsweek in 1972 to become a vice president for corporate communications at RCA.

BOSTON, June 27--Aides in the White House and the Democratic National Committee are encountering opposition in trying to get the March 4 Presidential primary in Massachusetts pushed back until late spring, a change that would help President Carter and make a candidacy by Senator Edward M. Kennedy more difficult.

WASHINGTON, June 27--The United States sent two experienced diplomats to Central America today to step up an effort aimed at replacing President Anastasio Somoza Debayle's Government in Nicaragua with a broadly based provisional government that would include representatives of the Sandinist guerrillas.

ISTANBUL, Turkey--Senol Sahin, 14 years old, has a thatch of blond hair, large, mournful hazel eyes and only one arm. The other was amputated when he was 6, after an accident that he says his stepfather caused in order to make him more effective as a beggar.

JERICHO, L.I., June 27--Sara Sage of Piping Rock, the 1978 winner, held a two-stroke lead after the second round of the 54-hole Women's Long Island Golf Association tournament today at Meadow Brook Club. She added a 79 today to yesterday's 73 for 152.
BALTIMORE, June 27 (AP)--The Baltimore Orioles rode the four-hit pitching of Jim Palmer to a 3-1 victory over Cleveland tonight for their 18th victory in the last 20 games.

GOOD news for musical dwellers in cramped quarters, as noted last week, is the recent appearance of mini-components-- sound gear shrunk to a fraction of the customary size.

Once again the Supreme Court has found a way to let affirmative action live. The Municipal Assistance Corporation of New York State, moving ahead with its financing plans for the second year of its four-year program to assist New York City, tentatively scheduled $1.04 billion of bond sales yesterday for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

Some 520,000 Americans--a quarter of 1 percent of the United States population--qualify as of the middle of this year, according to a marketing study released yesterday by the U.S. Trust Corporation.
