Muhammad Ali's associates spent most of yesterday trying to convince people that this time the champion had retired for good. Ali, speaking over the phone Tuesday, told a news conference in Newark that he had sent a letter to the World Boxing Association resigning his heavyweight title. In his two previous "retirements" Ali gave new meaning to the word by fighting again within months.

VIEWDATA is finally coming to the United States. Called by some the sleeping giant of the telecommunications world, viewdata is the name given to a group of electronic services that are expected eventually to transform the ordinary television set into a computer terminal.

Opponents of the long-delayed West Side highway project threw another obstacle in its way yesterday. They sued the Army Corps of Engineers to keep it from issuing a crucial dredge-and-fill permit for the $1.1 billion interstatehighway project.
VISALIA, Calif., June 27--Two years after California banned the toxic pesticide DBCP from agricultural use, the chemical has reappeared in drinking water in the San Joaquin Valley around Fresno.
The liner France, the last of the big trans-Atlantic liners, is to be rescued from retirement at anchor in Le Havre and sent back to sea.

A squad of personable and talented Swedish players will be fighting to defend its title in the European championships, which begin Saturday in Lausanne, Switzerland, Italy and France are expected to be their chief rivals, but Israel, Poland and Britain are not without hopes.

ELLEN GOULD, an attractivelooking singer and actress, is trying her big voice over an ambitious testing range in a short one-woman show called "Confessions of a Reformed Romantic," subtitled "A Classical Cabaret Piece," at the South Street Theater Company on West 42d Street.

For the first time yesterday, the Treasury Department set the rate that will govern new variable-rate savings certificates that will be offered by banks and savings institutions. It announced that the average yield on its four-year notes for the five business days ended June 26 was 8.85 percent.
Young Rubicam Inc., already the largest domestic advertising agency, is expected to become the largest worldwide American agency on Oct. 1, when it acquires Marsteller Inc.

HARTFORD, June 27--Most gas stations here have purchase limits and hourlong lines, when they are open at all. The only requirement is that the customer be in an airplane.

Energy stocks and takeover situations posted the market's best gains yesterday as prices generally steadied after two days of decline. Wall Street analysts said that investors apparently had become reconciled to an increase to around $20 a barrel for the benchmark price of imported oil.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 27 (Reuters)--Australia's six million workers were given a 3.2 percent pay rise today to compensate for an increase in the cost of living in the six months ended March 31. DETROIT, July 1 (AP)--Dissatisfaction with public education and increasing violence in the schools are expected to be among the key issues open for discussion as the National Education Association opens its 117th annual convention tomorrow.

The executive director of New York City's five-day Harbor Festival 1979, which began Saturday and ends tomorrow, said yesterday that because of fundraising and publicity problems, "we fell far short of what we wanted to do."

As gasoline lines shortened in the New York metropolitan area yesterday, Governor Carey imposed a minimum-sale requirement in the city and surrounding suburban counties to discourage "topping off" by motorists who already have nearly full tanks. Drivers will be charged at least $5 for any purchase for a fourcylinder car and at least $7 for cars with six cylinders or more.

THE war against illiteracy is being lost. Even though the proportion of illiterate adults in the world has declined from 44.4 percent to 32, percent since 1950, their actual number has increased from 700 million to 810 million, according to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO).

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 2--The energy crisis, a rising inflation rate, SALT and the Middle East have overshadowed President Carter's human rights policy of late. But in Latin America, where human rights and their denial are anything but abstractions, Mr. Carter's policy continues to put the United States in a more favorable light than is usual.

HARTFORD, July 3--Gov. Ella T. Grasso is scheduled to announce tomorrow that Connecticut will buy 12 selfpropelled railroad cars for Amtrak to run from New Haven through Hartford to Springfield, Mass.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 3 (AP)-- Iran has set contract prices of $19.70 to $19.90 per barrel of heavy crude oil and $21 to $22 for light crude following last month's pricefixing meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the National Iranian Oil Company said today.

THE NATIONAL BALLET OF CANADA returned to New York last night with Rudolf Nureyev, the first time since 1976 that Mr. Nureyev has appeared with the company from Toronto. In 1973, his drawing power as a guest artist enabled the troupe to make its local debut in an opera-house setting and with a full-evening opera-house ballet.

SHANGHAI, June 30--In the Shanghai Municipal Prison, a forbidding sootstained complex of bulky concrete buildings, the number of political prisoners has fallen sharply in recent years, according to the prison's chief political commissar.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 3--Only hours after representatives of the International Amateur Basketball Federation reprimanded Coach Bobby Knight for a temperamental outburst last night, the United States men's team crushed Cuba, 85-53, tonight and remained undefeated in the Pan American Games.
Ernest H. Meili, a former vice chairman of the J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation, died yesterday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

Ocean Spray Cranberries Inc., with sales of $160 million and equity of $28 million, yesterday became one of the smallest companies ever to tap the commercial paper market.

Shareholders of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company filed suit yesterday charging that the company violated securities laws in the sale of a 42 percent controlling interest to a West German group.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 3--The recent executions in Ghana have brought international protests, apparently forcing the new military Government to renounce further use of capital punishment in its drive to end corruption.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday announced the start of a nationwide campaign to defeat a proposed constitutional amendment prohibiting the busing of students beyond their neighborhood schools.

BACK in the 1960's, when the Dow Jones industrial average was suffering some downward jolts, Keith Funston became perturbed lest in vestors become unsettled. Thereupon, the president of the New York Stock Exchange hit upon the idea of splitting the Dow average 10 for 1. Such a move, he reasoned, would minimize the appearance of any drastic market declines.
The owner of a Harlem record shop was killed yesterday by a gunman who walked into the shop, shot him in the face and chest and fled, the police said.

DU PONT, Wash.--The Fourth of July is special to this former company town of fewer than 400 people on Puget Sound. Here, in 1841, an American naval officer, Capt. Charles Wilkes, is said to have celebrated the first Independence Day west of the Missouri.

The United States Postal Service is not out to sabotage etiquette, but etiquette was apparently on its way to sabotaging the post office. Those little informal cards, beloved by generations of traditionalists, will be out, as of July 15, unless delivered by hand or pigeon. Put one in the mail after the cutoff date, and it's going to make a round trip right back to you.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 3 (Reuters) --At least 70 people died in a heat wave last week in which the temperature reached 118 degrees in the provinces of Sind and Punjab, it was reported today.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 (Reuters)-- The Union Oil Company of California said today that it had formed the Union Energy Mining division to handle the operation of its oil-shale and uranium resources. As previously reported, Union plans to construct a $130 million oil-shale project in Colorado with an initial capacity of 10,000 tons a day.

NEWARK, July 3 (AP)--Attorney General Griffin B. Bell, saying there was a need to protect relations with foreign governments, balked today at a request to disclose the names of people and countries whose mail was being scrutinized by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Bond prices drifted lower yesterday as the credit markets quieted down before the Fourth of July holiday. Bond dealers and investors seemed to be marking time, waiting for the statistics on money supply, employment, wholesale prices and consumer credit scheduled to be released later this week.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The Government today told two leading producers of synthetic fibers and chemicals, E.I. du Pont de Nemours Company and the Union Carbide Corporation, that they could raise prices in line with the more liberal of two Federal guide lines for voluntary price restraint.

CARACAS, Venezuela (UPI)--The Venezuelan state oil monopoly, Petroleos de Venezuela S.A., today announced "an important discovery" of medium-grade crude oil in the western state of Zulia. Initial tests show a daily production of approximately 5,000 barrels daily of mediumgrade crude, the company said.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI)--President Carter plans to visit at least three United States cities this month. On Saturday, he will fly to Louisville, Ky., for a meeting of the National Governors Association. On July 16, he will fly to Kansas City, Mo., to speak to a meeting of the National Association of Counties. Later that day he will fly to Detroit to speak to the convention of the Communications Workers of America.

TUCSON, Ariz., July 1--Arizona's Atomic Energy Commission, under pressure from Federal regulators whose recommendations it at first ignored, is moving to shut permanently a manufacturing plant that has contaminated a school kitchen, an old people's center and other parts of its neighborhood with radioactive material.

WASHINGTON, July 3--The Carter Administration has decided to ask Congress to approve an agreement that would expand trade with China, leaving unclear whether a similar agreement with the Soviet Union would be submitted at the same time, Administration officials said today.

STOCKHOLM, July 3 (AP)--Steve Scott of the United States passed Eamonn Coghlan with about 50 yards left and won the feature mile at an international track and field meet tonight. The first 10 finishers in the 13man field were timed in under 3 minutes 59 seconds.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 3--Five officers of Nicaragua's National Guard today declared their support of the Sandinist rebels and their hostility toward President Anastasio Somoza Debayle, their former commander.

BONN, July 3--With arguments that West Germany's responsibility before history was at stake, a majority in the lower house of Parliament overcame strong opposition today and voted to continue the prosecution of war criminals of the Nazi era.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)-- Home mortgage rates rose in June by the largest amount for any month this year, the Government reported today.

CARSON CITY, Nev., July 3 (AP)-- Gov. Robert List, saying he was "fed up" with the dangers involved, has ordered the closing of a nuclear waste dump near Beatty after a truck carrying radioactive waste to the site sprang a leak.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 3--Even if President Carter decides to continue the freeze on American troop withdrawals from Korea, Defense Secretary Harold Brown has told South Korean leaders that the United States remains committed to their eventual withdrawal, according to a senior Administration official.

TOKYO, July 3 (AP)--The president of Japan's Nissan Motor Company, maker of Datsun cars, said today that its export shipments to the United States would increase in fiscal 1979 because of a growing demand for fuelefficient cars.

The first Big Apple Games, co-sponsored by the city's Board of Education and the state's Division of Youth, will begin tomorrow at eight high schools in the five boroughs.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 3-- After seven years' labor, an international treaty on the exploitation of the moon's resources was approved by the 47-member Committee on Outer Space today.

ABOARD S.S. SURVEYOR, off Alaska--The average American eats only, one pound of fish a month, as against about four pounds of poultry and 14 pounds of meat. Two-thirds of the fish consumed is imported, which, Richard Frank observes, has some doleful implications.
The American Broadcasting Companies yesterday created a division to develop and market programming for the burgeoning technologies of cabletelevision, video disks and home video recorders.

WASHINGTON, July 3--A recent United States intelligence analysis reports stepped-up Cuban aid to the Sandinist guerrillas in Nicaragua but also says Havana's policy is cautious and designed to avoid direct Cuban military participation and the risk of confrontation with Washington.

The Jets signed Matt Robinson, the quarterback, yesterday to a three-year contract estimated at $100,000 a season. Robinson led the team to six victories in 11 starts filling in for the injured Richard Todd. He passed for 2,002 yards and 13 touchdowns.
SAN SALVADOR, July 3 (UPI)--Two Britons held captive by a leftist guerrilla group since Nov. 30 were released late yesterday, the British Embassy con firmed today.

Warren, in a ruling in United States District Court in Milwaukee, said that there was no evidence to show that Citibank had provided Paccar Inc., a truck company, with inside information about the Harnischfeger Corporation in preparation for Paccar's proposed takeover of the heavy equipment producer.

WEST BERLIN, July 3 (AP)--Toni Schmucker, the general manager of Volkswagenwerk A.G., presented the giant auto maker's supervisory board today with a record investment program designed to meet worldwide demand for economical compact cars.

MONTREAL, July 2 (UPI)--Canadian newsprint production fell some 6 percent in May to 720,000 metric tons, and dropped 2 percent for the first five months of 1979 compared with the same period last year, according to a report today by the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association.

LOS ANGELES, July 2 (UPI)-- Global Marine Inc. confirmed that a commercial has discovery had been made in the High Island area of the Gulf of Mexico off the Texas coast. Global Marine has a 42.3 percent interest in the tract. Mesa Petroleum, the operator, has a half interest.

WTCG-TV in Atlanta and KTTV in Los Angeles are superstations. ILDIRI, Turkey--The small finger of land on the Aegean coast containing the village of Ildiri has been occupied for at least 28 centuries under its ancient name of Erythrai. HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 7--Into every Henley Royal Regatta a little rain must fall. Today's shower occurred during the luncheon interval, as picnic baskets and umbrellas opened simultaneously. Apart from making the cream run a little more freely over the strawberries, the rain did nothing to dampen the enthusiasm of the record crowd cheering the 131st rowing of this classic regatta.

PARAMUS, N.J. EMILIE TAYLOR says that Americans don't know beans about beef. She believed then, as she does now, that the best defense against high meat prices is not a boycott or a protest, but a well-informed consumer.

NEW DELHI, July 18--President N. Sanjiva Reddy asked the leader of India's second largest party today to attempt to form a government that would end this country's crisis of leadership.

A house guest in an Upper West Side building gained entrance to a female neighbor's apartment Tuesday afternoon with a gift of a bowl of salad, then threatened torture and rape before stabbing her in the back and leaping to his death from a 10th-floor window. The woman, naked and suffering a wound that had penetrated her chest, left a trail of blood as she escaped by running to the lobby.

WASHINGTON, July 18--Energy Department investigators have concluded that American oil companies have not diverted foreign crude oil or gasoline away from the United States, a department official reported today.

The Celanese Corporation said the Internal Revenue Service was expected to notify it of proposed deficiencies on Celanese corporate income tax returns filed from 1970 through 1973.
For the third time in three years, Simon Schuster has set up an independent hardcover publishing house, the Linden Press, which will be a wholly owned subsidiary of the parent company.

EASTON, Md., July 18 (AP)--Some 200 to 300 people were evacuated from their homes for a short time early today when a cloud of ammonia formed over a leaking storage tank near Easton. A valve on one of the storage tanks, owned by the Kerr-McGee Corporation and leased to a local distributor, "apparently was open or broken," said Alan Smith, a dispatcher for the Talbot County Fire Control Board.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 18 --The Cosmos, receiving an excellent performance in goal from Hubert Birkenmeier, rebounded from two losses at home and defeated the Strikers, 4-3, tonight at Lockhart Stadium.

BUCKEYE, Ariz., July 18 (AP)--High winds pushed a Greyhound bus off the road and on to its side yesterday, injuring 17 of its 24 passengers, the Arizona Department of Public Safety said. Three persons were seriously injured. The bus was on its way to Memphis when it was struck by winds of 60 to 70 miles an hour on Interstate 10.

TOKYO, July 18 (AP)--Increased imports drove Japan's current-account balance of payments in the first six months of 1979 into the red for the first time in four years, the Finance Ministry announced today. The ministry said the nation ran a deficit of $1.68 billion through June, a sharp turnaround from the $8.55 billion surplus in the yearearlier period.

A City Bar Association committee yesterday called "entirely appropriate" the decision last April by Judge Bruce McM. Wright of Criminal Court to release without bail a man accused of the attempted murder of a police officer.
MIAMI, July 18 (AP)--A forensic dentist testified today that the teeth shown in a photograph of Theodore R. Bundy's mouth made the bite marks found on a slain female college student.

DETROIT, July 18 (AP)--The American Motors Corporation reported today that it had earnings in the third fiscal quarter of $15.1 million, or 49 cents a share, up 147.5% from the $6.1 million, or 20 cents a share, it earned in the third quarter of the 1978 fiscal year. Net sales for the three months ended June 30 were a record $798 million, up 13.5 percent from $703 million a year ago, the company said.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 18 (AP)-- Bjorn Borg dropped his first two service games but came back strongly to defeat Christophe Freyss of France in two sets today in the $110,000 Swedish open tennis championship.

THE program for Tuesday night's Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall, the season's second, might have been chosen according to the whims of I Ching. As so often happens, the selection must have been dictated by the accident of which musicians were available, rather than by any compelling programmatic philosophy or logic.

MONROVIA, Liberia, July 18--The surface harmony at the conference of heads of state of the Organization of African Unity, which was disrupted at the opening session yesterday, suffered further blows today from speeches by President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and by Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, the Nigerian leader.

Banking sources in New York said that they were not surprised that Iran had canceled the pipeline project. And they added that it was doubtful that the new regime in Iran would have been capable of producing enough gas to send through the pipeline even if it were built.
MONOCHROMATIC gardens are rather a rarity today. In New York City they are almost unheard of; yet it is in vibrant and colorful urban settings that one-tone gardens can be most restful and striking.

A similar "song" with the catchy title "A Bushel for a Barrel" is ...

WASHINGTON, July 18--The United States applied heavy pressure today on Nicaragua's former President, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, and his successor to support a peaceful transfer of power to a guerrilla-backed provisional government, and Carter Administration officials reported subsequently that the peace plan appeared to be taking hold.

ST. ANNES, England, July 18--Bill Longmuir, a 26-year-old English golfer of modest talent, struck a hot putting streak today and led the windblown, chilly first round of the 108th British Open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)-- Executives of four oil companies said today that they were prepared to swear under oath that they know of no conspiracy to hold gasoline off the market in anticipation of higher prices.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18--The California Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether a public investigation of its members' conduct was constitutional and was warned that unless it acted the investigation might never be properly completed.

WICHITA, Kan., July 18--Middle Western farmers are bringing in a bumper wheat crop and receiving unusually high prices for their product, but the very abundance is causing severe storage and transportation problems.

IF you're looking for a small summer place, Ann Gatto-Cimmelli may have just the thing. The New York craftsman makes gazebos that stand one or two feet tall and are a pleasure to look at. Most are fancifully Victorian, but now and then, Mrs. Gatto-Cimmelli does some Gothic styles and custom-ordered designs.

WHEN the designer Michael Springer first visited the apartment that his client David Rus sell, a partner in a Wall Street securities concern, was about to move into, Mr. Springer was struck by its possibilities.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 18--Iran has canceled the export segment of an 868mile natural-gas pipeline that it was constructing to supply the Soviet Union, West Germany, France, Austria and Czechoslovakia, officials here disclosed today.

Mayor Koch said yesterday that he wanted the city to receive 12 percent of the profits on table games and 50 percent of slot machine profits as its price for support of a constitutional amendment legalizing gambling casinos in New York State.

I HAVE spent a good deal of time in model rooms. Their evocative, empty spaces have done a lot to shape my life. As a child-wanderer in museums, I discovered 18th-century France in the silent bolserie of the recreated Louis XV salons of New York's Metropolitan Museum.
LOS ANGELES, July 18 (AP)-- A Federal judge has reversed his 10-year-old decision that kept four American auto makers from sharing research information on automobile pollution control devices.

PARIS, July 18--The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the target of sometimes strong rhetoric from the Carter Administration, is nevertheless facing no practical threat as a result of the West's efforts to deal with the energy crisis.

SEATTLE, July 18--With his 6-foot5-inch, 230-pound body clothed in a bright yellow uniform, Dave Parker could not quite hide in a corner of the Kingdome during the 50th All-Star Game. On the contrary, the Pittsburgh right fielder was highly visible and served the cause of highly paid players everywhere.
WHEN Vera Rechulski takes a bath in her 23d-floor apartment she luxuriates not only in the bath but in an expansive view of the city provided by a floor-to-ceiling window.
The stock market was shaken early yesterday by Tuesday's news that the entire Cabinet and senior White House staff aides had offered President Carter their resignations.
Ben W. Heineman, president of Northwest Industries and a director of the First Chicago Corporation, sold 100,000 shares of First Chicago on June 13, the New York Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday.

Harold S. Geneen, chairman of the board of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, has been negotiating with European and American banks for multimillion-dollar loans to start a major venture not associated with I.T.T., industry sources disclosed yesterday.

POINT PLEASANT BEACH, N.J., July 18--In a race marred by heavy rain and thunderstorms, Rocky Aoki of New York City, driving a 38-foot Cougar catamaran, churned across the finish line off Manasquan inlet today to win the $50,000 Benihana Grand Prix offshore powerboat race.

DESPITE the fact that many teachers say they feel that two of the best reasons for teaching are July and August, hundreds of them have sacrificed some vacation time to stay in school and attend the Lincoln Center Institute.
Three monkeys--Zachary, Brian and Charlie--escaped from their cage in the Central Park Zoo yesterday by working on a defective padlock until it gave way.
The Juilliard School has been given $2 million to help talented young American playwrights.

One of the most beautiful species of bamboo, called "umbrella," has begun to blossom for the first time in 100 years in northern Europe and will soon bloom throughout the United States and the rest of the world. After that, all the world's umbrella bamboo will die.
A preview tonight from 5 P.M. to 9 P.M. opens a new crafts show by artists from the Southeastern states that will continue through Aug. 25.

Some months ago, President Carter asked Congress for modest, sensible changes in Social Security to reduce the need for raising the payroll tax again. The Administration proposed, for example, curtailing some burial benefits and stopping subsidies to affluent student survivors. But Congress is so wary of offending beneficiaries that the House refused to touch even these generous benefits.
Recent executive changes at NBC form a pattern that indicates the direction Fred Silverman is taking in the remaking of the National Broadcasting Company.
With half a mile to go, harness racing's most expensive yearling purchase was pacing fifth and beginning to tire.

American Airlines reported yesterday that its second-quarter profits surged 117.1 percent, with a net of $95.3 million, or $3.22 a share, up from $43.9 million, or $1.43 a share, in the quarter ended June 30, 1978.

MIAMI, July 18 (AP)--After dumping heavy rain on islands ringing the northeastern Caribbean and causing widespread flash flooding, the tropical storm Claudette weakened today, the National Hurricane Center reported.

WASHINGTON, July 18--President Carter has made his long-time political aide, Hamilton Jordan, White House chief of staff as the first step in reshuffling his personal staff and Cabinet, the White House announced today.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon, July 18 (Reuters)--Two convicted murderers were executed by firing squad here today before a crowd of more than 10,000 people, officials said. The executions were the first in Gabon since the country became independent from France in 1960.
An 18-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and accused of murdering a teen-age girl because she had cried in uncontrollable terror during a holdup in a Crown Heights grocery on May 30.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18--Indochinese refugees are straining health services here "beyond capacity," but their rapidly increasing numbers pose no health threat to local residents, a senior public health official said today.

WASHINGTON, July 18--Two engineers for the company that supplied the nuclear reactor that broke down at Three Mile Island said today that they had warned their superiors a year earlier that a serious accident was possible but that the warning had not been passed on.

After a $13 million refurbishing that took 10 months, the Kalamazoo, a 659-foot-long Navy supply ship, left yesterday from the site of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard for Norfolk, Va., where the vessel will be reassigned to sea duty.

The trial of three young men accused of assaulting and seriously injuring six men in the Central Park Ramble last July opened yesterday with the surprise testimony of a witness who said the defendants left her apartment immediately before the attack, returned with a baseball bat and clothing covered with blood, and said that they had committed the assaults.

BECKET, MASS. DESPITE the depredations of this "gasless" summer, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival rolls on as comfortably as ever. On Tuesday the festival, now in its 47th season, presented the third mixed bill of its dance. If the blend was a familiar one of ballet and modern dance, there were still a few surprises.

The upward trend in the production of petroleum products was interrupted in the week ended July 13 as the operating rate of the nation's oil refineries dropped to 86.6 percent of capacity from 90.3 percent in the preceding week, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

First Boston Inc. said it earned $2.72 million in the second quarter, up 1.5 percent from the $2.68 million it earned in the second quarter of 1978. Revenues declined, to $27.8 million from $28.5 million in the comparable period last year.
"ASTONISH me," Serge Diaghilev once told Jean Cocteau. From 1909 to 1929, Diaghilev's Ballets Russes cham pioned choreographic astonishment.

NEW DELHI, July 18--The Dalai Lama, the exiled priestly king of Tibet, has declared in an interview here that there is no question of his returning soon to his Himalayan homeland, now incorporated into China. But he added that he still believed that some accommodation linking Marxism with the traditional religion and culture of his country was possible.

WASHINGTON, July 18--Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal said today that the price of gold was rising and the dollar falling because of a "climate of uncertainty" in Washington, but he stopped short of suggesting that the turmoil in the currency markets was related to his resignation offer or to the offers of other Cabinet members.

WASHINGTON, July 18--Secretary of Defense Harold Brown sought to assure the Senate today that the United States would be able to verify adequately the strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union, but his testimony brought to light unresolved issues and disputes.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)-- Housing construction rose last month to its highest level so far this year, the Government reported today, but the industry, which termed the performance a "statistical fluke," predicted a sharp falloff in coming months.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 (AP)--Ken Norton and Scott LeDoux, originally scheduled to fight in San Diego on Sunday, will meet on Aug. 19 in Minneapolis. The heavyweight bout was postponed because Norton suffered a torn cartilage in his rib cage during a sparring session Monday morning.

ELECTRODEPOSITION, an application of the principle that opposites attract, is taking on a rapidly expanding role in the nation's auto in dustry as a highly effective, fast, anticorrosive method of painting cars.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)--The Senate voted by a narrow margin today to finish its third office building at a cost nearly triple the estimate architects gave when the structure was first authorized seven years ago.

WHEN I lived in Greens Farms, Conn., I felt compassion for New York City's poor. When I moved next door to them on West 78th Street and found them throwing garbage in my backyard, my compassion vanished. This was a great lesson in the relationship between one's address and opinions and marked the beginning of my political education.

LONDON, July 18--The price of gold rose above $300 an ounce for the first time today and the dollar fell sharply as world financial markets reacted to uncertainties over President Carter's energy program and potential changes in his Cabinet.

HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., July 18-- The United Automobile Workers, acknowledging the critical financial condition of the Chrysler Corporation, notified company officials today that Chrysler would not be considered a possible strike target in the union's formal contract negotiations with the nation's three largest automobile makers, which began this week.

PEOPLE gifted with "patience, creativity, a searching mind and a passion for methodology" have what it takes to be come successful wallpaper hangers, says Stan Warshaw, headmaster and president of the United States School of Professional Paperhanging in Rutland, Vt.

CAIRO, July 18--Although the United Nations peacekeeping mandate in Sinai expires next week, Egypt, Israel and the United States have not yet come up with an alternative force to meet the provisions of the peace treaty.
The New York City Department of Health yesterday released the names of 15 food establishments that it said had violated the Health Code.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)-- Traffic on United States airlines rose 15.4 percent in the first half of 1979, and air travel in June was up 12.4 percent over June 1978, the Air Traffic Association reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)--An interagency panel is recommending that the Government press former President Richard M. Nixon to repay $37,358 for "nonprotective" security improvements included in the $702,321 that the Government spent on his San Clemente home.

Feminist groups called yesterday for a shake-up in the organization of the nation's 26,000 private foundations to insure more financing for women's projects that now receive less than 1 percent of their donations.

TWO things about Joseph H. Hirshhorn are common knowl edge. One is that he made a lot of money. The other is that he bought a lot of art, much of which is now in the museum that bears his name on the Mall in Washington.

RICHFIELD, Ohio, July 18 (AP)-- Nick Mileti, the president of the Cleveland Cavaliers, planned to interview Willis Reed, former New York Knicks coach, tomorrow for the coaching position of the National Basketball Association team.

The kidneys of a 21-year-old Soviet man involved in a fatal accident arrived in New York from Moscow yesterday, less than a month after the United States sent the kidney of a dead Virginia girl to the Soviet Union.
Al Rosen, after day-long meetings with the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, left Yankee Stadium last night still undecided about his future as president of the team.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)--Senator Harrison Schmitt renewed his campaign to give Congress a veto over Government regulations as a Senate subcommittee began hearings today on a bill that he failed to get through Congress last year.
IRVING SONN, who last January quit Ted Bates Company, where he was president of United States affili ates, is back in the business, this time as founder of Irv Sonn Advertising Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)-- Third-seeded Harold Solomon, faltering from fatigue, was upset by unseeded Rick Fagel, 6-3, 2-6, 6-4, today in the second round of the $175,000 Washington Star International men's tennis tournament.
Volatile price swings buffeted the precious metals market yesterday as gold and silver for both immediate and future delivery continued to set historic highs on both sides of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, July 18--Senator Jacob K. Javits has selected Elizabeth F. Defeis, a law professor at Seton Hall Law Center in Newark, for a Federal judgeship in the Eastern District of New York. If approved by President Carter and the Senate, the Brooklyn resident would become the first woman to sit on the bench in that district.

OMAHA, July 18--For the last two days, Vice President Mondale has been campaigning for public support of the pending Soviet-American treaty to limit offensive nuclear weapons. But the public, it seems, is more interested in the Carter Administration's proposals for reducing American dependence on foreign oil.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP)--A new Roper Poll suggests that public resentment toward taxes, such as that that gave rise to California's Proposition 13, is cooling off but that taxpayers would like to see the Federal Government limit spending.

WASHINGTON, July 18--In President Carter's two and a half years in the White House, one aspect of his stewardship has never wavered: his personal reliance on Hamilton Jordan and the steadily expanding power given the 34-year-old politician.

Employees of the Environmental Protection Agency and staff members of the Environmental Defense Fund have charged that the agency's proposed regulations on waste disposal have been rewritten to exempt some of the most toxic wastes in the country.

OTTAWA, July 18--Two days before the opening of a United Nations conference on Indochinese refugees, the Canadian Government today announced a cooperative effort with private groups to increase significantly the number of Southeast Asians that Canada will accept for resettlement.
The Treasury auctioned one-year bills yesterday at an average yield of 8.896 percent, up slightly from the previous sale of 8.829 percent.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 18 (AP)--Bob MacKinnon, former assistant coach with the Boston Celtics, was named today to a similar position with the New Jersey Nets.

ALBANY, July 18--Governor Carey announced today his veto of a bill that would have made some types of college fraternity hazing a crime, saying that adequate protections already existed and that the bill's provisions were so vague they would be hard to enforce.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 18 (UPI)-- The Florida Supreme Court today agreed to hear a request for a stay of execution for Howard V. Douglas, a condemned killer. The request said that the death penalty should not have been imposed because the jury had recommended mercy. The court set the hearing for 9:30 A.M. Friday, giving the Attorney General until 5 P.M. tomorrow to file arguments opposing the stay.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 18 (UPI)-- Four golfers were tied for the lead with scores of 2-under-par 140 today after the second round of the 57th annual New York State amateur golf tournament.

ALBANY, July 18--Angry Senate Republicans blocked two of Governor Carey's nominees to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority today after the Governor ignored the Senate majority leader's request that he reappoint a prominent Republican to the board.

TEHERAN, July 18--They marched again today in Iran, not by the hundreds, not by the thousands, but perhaps by the millions, chanting "Unity with Khomeini, the Koran is our way" and "Death to leftists, Carter, Sadat and Begin."
The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

CLEVELAND, July 18 (AP)--George L. Forbes, the outspoken City Council president and bitter opponent of Mayor Dennis J. Kucinich, was acquitted by a judge today on all charges stemming from alleged carnival kickbacks.

Thousands of taxi owners, protesting what they said was an inadequate rise in taxi fares, tied up traffic on New York City bridges and streets during the morning rush period yesterday by moving slowly to a rally at the Battery.
WASHINGTON, July 18--Congress has completed its annual appropriations for water projects, with the environmentalists and President Carter winning on two, losing on one, and drawing on two.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 18--When you're No. 3 you have to try harder-- much harder. Nobody knows that better than Pat Ryan, the third-string quarterback of the Jets.

"INFINITE Horizons: Space Beyond Apollo," being broadcast at 8:30 tonight, is not part of the "ABC News Closeup" series. Instead of dealing with facts of the past or present, this production offers speculations on the future. The occasion, of course, is tomorrow morning's 10th anniversary of the Apollo 1l moon landing.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 18--Jerry Courville Sr., the 44-year-old golfer from Norwalk, Conn., who underwent radical surgery to remove a malignancy four years ago, today finished playing 153 holes of winning, competitive golf that he began seven days ago over two of the most demanding golf courses in the metropolitan area-- Winged Foot and Quaker Ridge.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, July 18 (UPI)--Henry Rono of Kenya finished a disappointing seventh in a 3,000meter race tonight that was won by Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland.
WHITE PLAINS, July 18--A Westchester County grand jury has indicted two men in the May 10 murders of four Bedford Hills residents, a source close to the investigation said today.

FOR many years, all the concerts of the Washington Square Music Festival were held in the park itself unless bad weather forced retreat indoors into a hall lent by New York University. Now, however, a new custom seems to be in the making ...

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI)--An $11.9 million civil suit was filed today by a textile workers union against the J.P. Stevens company, three other concerns and officials of Milledgeville, Ga., alleging they conspired to keep unions out of the area.

A 30-year-old Nigerian citizen who studied at Long Island University in Brooklyn pleaded guilty yesterday to defrauding the Federal Government of student-loan funds available only to United States citizens.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 18--A pair of 2-year-old fillies sired by Songoan, who is now standing at the Pine Hollow Stud Farm's stable in Pine Bush, N.Y., triumphed in rich New York Sire Stakes events at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

PARIS, July 18--This year's oil price rise will result in at least 12 months of economic stagnation in the United States, while other industrial countries will also face slower growth, more unemployment, rising inflation and aggravated payment difficulties in the coming year, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today in its latest report on the economic outlook.

OFFERING what could be called a truly inter-American premiere, the National Ballet of Cuba presented a new ballet by a Canadian choreographer Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. To many dance fans, Brian Macdonald's "Prologue for a Tragedy" will seem both familiar and surprising.
The Federal Government said yesterday that it had taken action to fine Pacific Southwest Airlines $385,000 for an apparent "pattern" of rules violations in maintaining and operating its aircraft.
Substantially higher earnings for the second quarter of 1979 were reported yesterday by several major chemical concerns, among them Dow, Allied and Celanese.

TEL AVIV, July 18--Finance Minister Simcha Ehrlich, accused of indecisiveness in dealing with Israel's economic ills, said today that he was considering resigning from the Cabinet.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 18-- Faced with the rapid disintegration of the National Guard, Nicaragua's new Government decided today to hand over power to a rebel-named provisional junta that set up its temporary capital in the northern city of Leon early this morning.

LHASA, Tibet, July 17--They come from all over the high plateau of Chinese Central Asia, pilgrims in black robes, silver daggers at their belts, wearing high canvas boots and carrying chalices laden with yak butter for offerings. It could be a scene from a medieval tapestry.

EVERY proper mother's child is given music lessons as part of his entitlement. Seldom does a virtuoso emerge from among children so privileged, but that is not the intention anyway. The intention is to offer music as a gift, along with life's other good gifts. And music, too, in the proper dose, provides just the right degree of restlessness of spirit that could lead to the approved noble aspirations.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 18--The City of Stamford agreed in Federal court here today to hire one minority-group applicant for the Fire Department for every white applicant hired, until the department has a 17.5 percent minority composition.

SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y.--Labor union leaders are under the gun. Corporations and the Government, with tentative public backing, are prodding them to soften demands while we fight stagflation. Rank-and-file union members are pushing them to reverse the recent effects of economic instability: stagnating real incomes, spreading health-and-safety hazards, and mounting job insecurity. How should union leaders evaluate the critical choices they face? And how should the broader public respond to the unions' dilemma?

WHEN drip-dry and permanent-press sheets and pillowcases arrived, many women discarded their cotton linens, even the ones embroidered by their mothers and grandmothers. But household linens, like clothes, are subject to the vagaries of fashion.
KUWAIT, July 18 (AP)--The Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, has promised to send President Hafez al-Assad of Syria 10 MIG-25 jet fighters, a Kuwait newspaper said today.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 19--Mark Gastineau was beating up on Giants in the one-on-one drills before the scrimmage proper. He was not looking like a rookie who says all he wants to do is make the Jets' roster and "play in my first professional game."

NEW DELHI, July 19--In the power vacuum left by the collapse of the Government headed by Morarji R. Desai, responsibility for guiding and preserving Indian democracy has fallen to one man, N. Sanjiva Reddy, the blunt, strong-willed President.

The staff of the New York State Department of Public Service has called for rejection of plans by the Long Island Lighting Company to build two nuclear power plants in Jamesport, L.I., giving as one of its reasons the lessons learned from the Three Mile Island nuclear accident in Pennsylvania.

Dr. Nathan Bailey, who had served six three-year terms as president of the Christian and Missionary Alliance, was killed in an automobile accident near Nottingham, England, on July 10, it was learned here yesterday. Dr. Bailey, whose wife, Mary, was seriously injured in the accident, was 69 years old.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19--Dave Hirsch won his third straight race at Larchmont Race Week today to remain the only undefeated skipper at this venerable yachting event. Hirsch who campaigns a blue-hulled boat of the J-24 Class named Ukelele Lady out of Stratford, Conn., was unimpressed.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 19--In a major victory today for organized labor's faltering efforts in Sun Belt states, the United Automobile Workers union won the right to represent workers at a new General Motors Corporation plant here by a ratio of nearly 2 to 1. The official vote was 1,479 votes to 658.

The Colonial Commercial Corporation has acquired an option to buy 5.65 acres of land in Atlantic City for a proposed casino-hotel. The option was acquired from King International, with which Colonial has plans to merge. The casino-hotel complex will cost an estimated $75 million, if financing can be negotiated and approval obtained from regulatory groups.
WASHINGTON, July 19--Secretary of the Treasury W. Michael Blumenthal maintained today that he had resigned voluntarily and that there had been "no coercion at all."

A two-ton granite sculpture that was toppled from its pedestal and smashed by vandals on a sidewalk at 77th Street and Madison Avenue last May, causing an outcry in the neighborhood, has been restored and will be remounted Sept. 15. Special clamps are expected to assure its security this time.

Congressman John Dingell of Michigan hopes to deflate the push for air bags in future cars with a mischievous piece of legislation. WASHINGTON, July 24--The Securities and Exchange Commission censured Blyth, Eastman, Dillon Company today and suspended the prominent Wall Street brokerage firm from market-making activities in three over-the-counter stocks for five days.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., July 24-- Government scientists, having completed their first detailed survey of the huge oil slick from a runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico, said today that they expected the slick's leading edge to reach United States waters in 10 to 14 days. MONROVIA, Liberia, July 22-- Some delegates to the Organization of African Unity meeting, which wound up its business here Saturday, were amused by such Liberian peculiarities as the fact that the American greenback, limp and brown from use, is the national currency, or that Monrovia's "finest" wear cast-off New York City police uniforms. Until a few years ago, George Washington was the police chief.

ATHENS--Five years have come and gone since the Greek regime disintegrated and left to the politicians the task of bringing the country back to normality. GENEVA, July 30--Lew Kowarski, a Russian-born French nuclear physicist, died of a stroke in a hospital here on Friday at the age of 72, it was announced today.

If Amtrak had as many riders as political friends, it would be coining money. But the passenger rail system needs all the financial help it can scrounge. Fares cover just a third of its costs; the rest must be paid by Washington. Even now, when energy conservation is a primary public concern, the price is too high.
Takeover developments produced large price changes in several stocks yesterday as the general market showed token gains.

As the credit markets inched ahead yesterday, encouraged by the strengthening of the dollar in foreign-exchange trading, Govennment securities dealers estimated that the Treasury's new three-year notes scheduled for sale this afternoon would probably yield 9.10 percent, give or take a little.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30-- The Security Council abruptly cut off a debate on Palestinian rights today amid indications the Carter Administration wanted time to assess what could be a shift in policy toward Israel. The Council debate was put off until Aug. 23.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)--State Department officials said today that they were pressing Czechoslovakia for access to three Americans arrested at the border on charges of trying to smuggle Bibles into the country.

WASHINGTON, July 30--The United States was forced today to delay a meeting it had hoped to convene with Egypt and Israel this week on resolving a dispute about an international force to oversee Israeli withdrawals from Sinai.

HOUSTON, July 30--The trial lawyers who are holding their annual convention here are entrepreneurs, the gamblers of the legal profession, taking fees from 15 to 40 percent of the award if they win a case and nothing if they lose.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters)-- President Carter today sent to the Senate for ratification a treaty signed with Panama last January on exchanging prisoners. The treaty would permit citizens of either nation convicted in the other country to serve their sentences in their home country if they wish.
For the diesel-powered motorist, long gasoline lines and odd-even days are only a phenomenon to observe as he briskly advances to the diesel pump, often open 24 hours a day.
A huge wave of selling sent gold, silver, platinum and copper futures plunging to their daily permissible limits yesterday in one of the broadest price breaks recorded in the New York metals market.

The heated and longstanding debate over whether teachers should be treated as "professionals" like doctors, nurses and practitioners of 28 other fields seems at last to be headed toward resolution in New York State--mainly because it is now being linked politically to the pressing issue of educational quality.

HARTFORD, July 30 (AP)-- "Jockey boy" statues have been disappearing from the lawns of homes in the Hartford area, and the "Black Jockey Liberation Army" says it will keep taking them until it has removed "all forms of bigotry."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Federal Trade Commission's suit to stop the Exxon Corporation from buying the Reliance Electric Company could establish new standards in antitrust law that would inhibit conglomerate mergers, antitrust lawyers say.
In a special rating comment in its Bond Survey published yesterday, Moody's Investors Service raised a warning flag over Chrysler Corporation securities.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 30 (AP)-- John Bayne Breckinridge, a Lexington lawyer and three-time Congressman, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

IT looks as though the Media Corporation of America might owe newspapers, magazines, outdoor advertis ing companies and broadcasters considerably more than the $9.5 million that Albert B. Shepard, its chairman and president, acknowledged it owed at a crowded creditors' meeting last Friday.

GENEVA, July 30 -- Most of the world's major airlines have agreed to seek approval from their governments to raise passenger fares and cargo rates on international routes by between 9 and 15 percent to meet higher fuel costs, the International Air Transport Association announced today.

THE fight is heating up again over the controversial proposal by the Internal Revenue Service that deals with the proper way to report interest earned on short-term obligations when the obligations overlap two calendar years.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 30 (Reuters) --Syrian troops and Lebanese right-wing militia forces battled with mortars and rockets in Beirut tonight.
TRENTON, July 30 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional zoning ordinances that limit the number of unrelated persons who may share a single housing unit.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)--The makers of Darvon, a popular pain-killing drug, have agreed to begin distributing voluntarily a warning telling of the hazards of using the drug in excess or with other drugs or alcohol, the Government said today.
PITTSBURGH, July 30--A day that started on a happy note for the Mets ended with an injury to Steve Henderson and an 8-5 defeat by the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Paul A. Volcker, chairman-designate of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that inflation had been caused by excessive growth of the money supply and suggested he would press for a reduction even if it should mean still higher interest rates.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI)--The Environmental Protection Agency said today that under new rules, gasoline stations may put leaded gas into cars designed to take unleaded fuel, but only in the event of a "bona-fide emergency."

WASHINGTON, July 30--The Washington Post and The Newspaper Guild, the union of editorial and clerical workers, signed a new contract today, ending a frequently embittered three-year lapse during which the company bargained intermittently and largely disregarded the terms of the expired contract.

BAR HARBOR, ME. LAST Wednesday afternoon as Anna Stanley went about her chores at the Jackson Laboratory here --cleaning the mouse cages, replenishing the food and water--she spotted a deformed baby mouse in a 5-day-Old litter of laboratory mice. The tiny creature had been born with no hind legs and a deformed front leg.

RICHMOND, July 30 (AP)--A Federal judge refused today to dismiss fraud and conspiracy charges against Smith Bagley, an R.J. Reynolds tobacco heir, and four co-defendants accused of conspiring to rig the price of stock in a food and textile conglomerate.

DETROIT, July 30--Peter C. Bommarito, president of the United Rubber Workers union, has challenged the integrity of the bargaining unit representing union members at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 30--Ambassador Lawrence A. Pezzullo responded to questions about reported attempts by defeated National Guard officers to organize counterrevolutionary actions by saying today that the United States was opposed to any intervention in the Nicaraguan revolution.
PEABODY, Kan., July 30 (AP)--A bank president's 25-year-old son was found dead on a dirt road north of here tonight, a day after he was abducted from his home.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)--Two Federal judges issued orders today to delay the possible disruption of power for Massena, N.Y.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Ju1y 30--While the Palestine Liberation Organization has suffered serious setbacks in the field recently, it has been gaining in its campaign to win international recognition.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that it had approved a 1 percent surcharge for the nation's freight railroads to offset higher fuel costs. The rate increase was effective last Saturday.

The Municipal Assistance Corporation sold $131 million in long-term bonds yesterday at an average interest rate that was lower by a full percentage point than the interest rate on its last issue, which was sold in March.

New York City and New York State lack effective controls on explosive, poisonous, corrosive and radioactive materials carried along highways and city streets, according to police, fire and transportation officials who testified yesterday before an Assembly subcommittee.

The dollar rose strongly against most foreign currencies yesterday. Dealers were unable to pin the rise on a particular news event, but pointed to encouragement about the nomination of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and about United States trade figures.

WASHINGTON, July 30--Leaders of the Senate Energy Committee outlined today the "fast track" legislation they plan to send to the floor in September to accelerate construction of synthetic fuel plants and other installations designed to reduce the nation's reliance on imported oil.
KUWAIT, July 30 (UPI) -- The Kuwaiti Oil Ministry announced today price increases on butane and propane gas exports ranging from 24 to 41 percent a metric ton.
The recent history of the United States would have been somewhat different if there had been no Herbert Marcuse, who died Sunday at the age of 81 while on a visit to his native Germany.

The head of the Harlem Hospital chapter of the municipal hospital workers union was reported yesterday in danger of losing the sight of one eye as the result of a fight involving an internal union dispute.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- President Carter said today that the intensive discussions he held at Camp David earlier this month and the "unbelievably favorable" response received at the White House to his July 15 energy speech had restored his own "determination, self-assurance, confidence and will" as President.
ALBANY, July 30--The president of the Public Employees Federation spent 10 years on the state payroll working nearly full time for his union, the State Commission of Investigation charged today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters)-- The Boeing Company received a $116.2 million contract from the Air Force for offensive avionics, hardware and software, the Defense Department announced today.

The Continental Oil Company said that it would increase its capital spending program for this year by $130 million. The increase, primarily for exploration and development of oil and natural gas in the United States, brings the company's total planned outlays for the year to $1.5 billion, up 36 percent from its 1978 expenditures.
PARIS, July 30 (Reuters)--Maxim's, the celebrated Paris restaurant, has been declared a historical monument by the French Government.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 (UPI)--Shirley Mason, a star of silent films, died of cancer Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. Miss Mason, who lived with her sister, Viola Dann, in the Marina del Rey area, was 79 years old.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP)--A tree falling on a power line and a mechanical failure at a generating plant caused a huge power failure today that affected 400,000 residents of Massachusetts and Rhode Island, utility officials said.

HARTFORD, July 30--A special session of the General Assembly this morning overwhelmingly overturned Gov. Ella T. Grasso's veto of a bill to delay auto-emissions testing. But the legislators let stand the veto of a bill that would have cut the minimum wage for waiters and waitresses.
A JAPANESE team has reported finding a highly efficient method of converting sunlight directly into electric energy, using a component of spinach as an intermediary.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters)-- The United States is willing to consider a request by Nicaragua's new Government for arms and military training, the State Department said today.

MOSCOW, July 30--The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia today denied that any decision had been made to expel David Satter, an American journalist who represents The Financial Times of London here.

The Syntex Corporation said that the Food and Drug Administration had accepted the company's scientific data demonstrating the safety of its anti-arthritis drug, Naprosyn, and had abandoned all proceedings to remove the drug from the market.

Today is July 31, and it means that drivers of cars having odd or even numbers as the last number on their license plates can buy gasoline in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

MANKATO, Minn., July 30 (AP)-- Carl Eller, a five-time all-pro during his 16-year National Football League career as a defensive end for Minnesota, was traded by the Vikings to Seattle today.

Swiss Aluminium Ltd., also known as Alusuisse, said that its takeover of the Maremont Corporation was nearly complete, with 93 percent of the American company's common stock tendered to the Swiss concern at $42 a share.

Texas Instruments, makers of semiconductors, calculators, watches and missile guidance systems, reported yesterday that it had a 30 percent jump in second-quarter net income to $44.6 million, or $1.95 a share, from $34.3 million, or $l.50 a share, a year ago. Jack Gregory, defensive captain of the Giants, left training camp at Pleasantville, N.Y., yesterday afternoon and reportedly was destined for his Mississippi home.

ABC-TV, which has been striving the last few years to improve its lineup of affiliated stations, recently has added four more stations to its chain in small cities where the network previously had no regular outlets. WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters)-- Productivity in the United States, a key factor in the inflation rate, suffered its sharpest drop in more than five years during the second quarter of 1979, the Labor Department reported today.

PEKING, July 31--The Chinese Communist Party appears to be moving toward a campaign to weed out corrupt and incompetent officials and to end factionalism. Unlike previous purges, the campaign appears designed to be carried out by regular procedures in an attempt to restore the rule of law.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP)-- A grain-price boom that began in late spring helped raise the average prices farmers got for raw food and fiber products by 0.75 percent in July, the Agriculture Department said today. Farm prices in July were up 14 percent from a year earlier.

Rachel I. Becker, daughter of Beverly J. Backer of Slidell, La., and the late Rev. Robert Becker, was married yesterday afternoon to warren, S. Edelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Edelman of West Brighton, S.I. Judge Gustave Fritchie of the Parish Court of Slidell performed the ceremony in his chambers.
American Brands Inc. said yesterday that its board had increased the quarterly dividend on its common stock to $1.25 a share from $1.125, payable Sept. 1 to stockholders of record Aug.10.

Cornelius P. Haugh, a financial consultant specializing is Far East investments, and his wife, Jane, a community leader on the West Side of Manhattan, were killed Saturday is an automobile accident in Glens Falls, N.Y. Mr. Haugh was 43 years old and his wife was 41.

HIGHLAND PARK, Mich., July 31-- The financially troubled Chrysler Corporation, reporting the largest quarterly loss in its history, said today that it had asked the Federal Government to provide it with up to $1 billion in cash over the next 18 months. It also asked for some relief from Federal requirements on exhaust emissions.

ARLINGTON, Tex., July 31 (AP)-- The management of the Texas Rangers reluctantly offered Oscar Gamble to the New York Yankees tonight after Commissioner Bowie Kuhn objected to certain provisions of a deal that would have sent three minor leaguers and a player to be named later to New York for Mickey Rivers.

LONDON, July 31--The Nigerian nationalization of B.P. holdings had been a topic of speculation here for some weeks and is seen as a retaliatory move against the moves of Britain's new Conservative Government to recognize Zimbabwe Rhodesia.

Paul A. Volcker, chairman-designate of the Federal Reserve Board, says current Federal prohibitions on interstate banking should be liberalized.

The dollar was generally higher against foreign currencies yesterday, its biggest rise scored against the British pound, which was hurt by news that Nigeria was nationalizing the British Petroleum Company's holdings in that nation. The price of gold dropped below $300 an ounce.

Reflecting the demand for its commercial jet airliners, second-quarter net income of the Boeing Company climbed 55 percent to $120.1 million, or $1.87 a share, from $77.5 million, or $1.21 a share, in the similar three months last year, the company reported yesterday.

NEWARK, Aug. 6 The President's chief adviser on domestic affairs, Stuart E. Eizenstat, making his first visit to a major city to see Government programs in operation, today urged passage of the President's urban-aid program, saying that "the long-term future of America is in its urban areas."
